titleStmt.title: When You See Me You Know Me (Henry the Eighth) 1605
titleStmt.author: Rowley, Samuel

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

keywords.term: Henry, -- VIII, -- King of England, -- 1491-1547 -- Drama -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: When you see me, you know me.
Or the famous chronicle history of King Henry the eight, with the birth and virtuous life of Edward prince of Wales.
As it was played by the high and mighty prince of Wales his servants.
By Samuel Rowly, servant to the prince.
London, imprinted for Nathaniel butter, and are to be sold in Paul's churchyard near saint Austin's gate. 1605.

div.head: When you see me, you know me.
div.stage: Enter the Cardinal with the ambassadors of France, in all state and royalty, the purse and mace before him.

sp.speaker: Wolsey.
sp.l: Gentlemen give leave: you great ambassadors,
From Francis the most christian King of France:
My lord of Paris, and lord Bonevet,
Welcome to England: since the King your master
Entreats our furtherance to advance his peace;
Giving us titles of high dignity,
As next elect to Rome's supremacy.
Tell him we have so wrought with English Henry
(Who, as his right hand loves the Cardinal)
That undelayed, you shall have audience:
And this day will the King in person sit
To hear your message, and to answer it.

sp.speaker: Bonevet.
sp.l: Your grace hath done us double courtesy:
For so much doth the King our master long,
To have an answer of this embassage.
As minutes are thought months till we return.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: And that is the cause his highness moves your grace,
To quick dispatch betwixt the King and him:
And for a quittance of your forwardness,
And hopeful kindness to the crown of France,
Twelve reverent Bishops are sent post to Rome,
Both from his highness and the emperor,
To move Campeus and the Cardinals,
For your election to the papal throne,
That Wolsey's head may year the triple crown.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We thank his highness for remembering us.
And so salute my lord the emperor,
Both which (If Wolsey be made Pope of Rome)
Shall be made famous through all Christendom.
How now 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Sir William Cumpton from his highness comes,
To do a message to your excellence,

sp.speaker: Vvool.
sp.l: Delay him a while, and tell him we are busy,
Mean time my lords you shall with draw yourselves,
Our private conference must not be known,
Let all your gentlemen in their best array,
Attend you bravely to King Henry's court,
Where we in person presently will meet you:
And doubt not we'll prevail succesfully.

sp.speaker: Bone.
sp.l: But hath your grace yet moved his highness' sister,
For kind acceptance of our sovereign's love.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: I have, and by the King's means finished it,
And yet it was a task, I tell ye lords,
That might have bene imposed to Hercules,
To win a lady of her spirit and years.
To see her first love crowned with silver hairs,
As old King Lewes is, that bedrid lies,
Unfit for love, or worldly vanities.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: But 'tis is country's peace the King respects,

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: We think no less, and we have fully wrought it,
The emperor's forces that were levied,
To invade the frontiers of lo Burgundy,
Are stayed in Brabant by the King's command,
The admiral Hayward that was lately sent,
With threescore sail of ships and pinnaces,
To batter down the towns in Normandy,
I● by our care for him, called home again:
Then doubt not of a fair successful end;
Since Wolsey is esteemed your sovereign's friend.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: We thank your excellence, and take our leaves,

sp.speaker: Vvool.
sp.l: Hast ye to court, lie meet ye presently.

sp.speaker: Bone.
sp.l: Good morrow to your grace.

sp.speaker: Vvol.
sp.l: Good morrow lords, go call sir William Cumpton in,
We must have narrow eyes, and quick conceit,
To look into these dangerous stratagems,
I will effect for France, as they for me:
If Wolsey to the Pope's high state attain,
The league is kept, or else here break't again,
Now good sir William

sp.speaker: Cum.
sp.l: The King my lord entreats your reverent grace,
There may be had some private conference,
Betwixt his highness and your excellence,
Before he hear the French ambassadors,
And wills you hasten your repair to him,

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We will attend his highness presently,
Bonner, see all our train be set in readiness,
That in our state and pomp pontificial,
We may pass on to grace King Henry's court,

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: I have a message from the Queen my lord,
Who much commends, and humbly thanks your grace,
For your exceeding love, and zealous prayers,
By your directions through all England sent:
To invocate for her sound prosperous help,
By heaven's fair hand in childbed passions.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We thank her highness that accepts our love,
In all cathedral churches through the land,
Are masses, dirges, and processions sung:
With prayers to heaven to bless her majesty,
And send her joy, and quick delivery:
And so sir William do my duty to her,
Queen Jane was ever kind and courteous,
And always of her subjects honoured.

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: I take my leave my lord.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: Adieu good knight we'll follow presently,
Now Wolsey work thy wits like gads of steel,
And make them pliable to all impressions,
That King and Queen and all may honour thee:
So toiled not Caesar in the state of room,
As Wolsey labours in the affairs of Kings:
As Hannibal with oil did melt the Alps:
To make a passage into Italy:
So must we bear our high pitched eminence
To dig for glory in the hearts of men.
Till we have got the papal diadem:
And to this end have I composed this plot,
And made a league between the French and us
And match their aged King in holy marriage,
With lady Mary royal Henry's sister:
That he in peace complotting with the emperor
May plead for us within the courts of Rome:
Wherefore was Alexander's fame so great,
but that he conquered and deposed Kings,
And where doth Wolsey fail to follow him,
That thus common death Kings and emperors,
Great England's lord have I so won with words:
That under colour of aduising him,
I overrule both counsel, court, and King:
Let him command, but we will execute.
Making our glory to outshine his fame
Till we have purchased an eternal name.
Now Boner, are those proclamations sent
As we directed to the sheriffs of London,
Of certain new devised articles,
For ordering those brothels called the stews?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: They are ready my lord, and the shrieve attends for them,

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: Dispatch him quickly, and haste after me;
We must attend the Kings high majesty.

div.stage: Sound trumpets, enter King Harry the eight, Queen Jane big with child, the Cardinal, Charles Brandon Duke of Suffolk, Dudlit, Graye, Compton, the lady Marry, the countess of Salisbury attending on the Queen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Charles Brandon, Dudly, and my good lord grey,
Prepare yourselves, and be in readiness,
To entertain these French ambassadors,
Meet them before our royal palace gate:
And so conduct them to our majesty.
We mean this day to give them audience.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Grey, we will my lord.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Le tone attend without.
And bring us word when they are coming on:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now Queen Jane (Mother of God) my love
Thou wilt never be able to sit half this time:
Ladies, I fear she'll wake ye, yer be long,
Methinks she bears her burden very heavily,
And yet good sister and my honoured lords,
If this fair hour exceed not her expect.
And pass the calendar of her accounts,
She will hear this embassage, Jane wilt thou nor

sp.speaker: Q: Jane,
sp.l: Yes my dear lord, I cannot leave your sight.
So long as life retains this mansion?
In whose sweet looks bright sovereignties in throned,
That make all nations love and honour thee,
Within thy frame sits awful majesty,
wreathed in the curled furrows of thy front:
Admired and feared even of thine enemies;
To be with thee, is my felicity.
Not to behold the state of all the world,
Could win thy Queen, thy sick unwieldy Queen,
To leave her chamber, in this mother's state.
But sight of thee unequal potent ate,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: God a-mercy Jane, reach me thy princely hand.
Thou art now a right woman, goodly, chief of thy sex;
Methinks thou art a Queen superlative,
Mother, a god this is a woman's glory,
Like good September vines laden with fruit.
How ill did they define the name of women,
Adding so soul a preposition:
To call it woe to man, 'tis woe from man.
If woe it be, and then who does not know,
That women still from men receive their woe.
Yes, heigh love men for it, but what's their gain,
Poor souls no more but travail for their pain;
Come, love thou art sad, call will Sommers in, to
Make her merry, where is the fool today,

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: He was met my liege they say at London
Early this morning with doctor Skelton,

sp.speaker: I'll.
sp.l: He's never from him, go let a groom be sent,
And fetch him home, my good lord Cardinal:
Who are the chief of these ambassadors?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Lord Bonevet the French high admiral,
And John de Mazo reverent Bishop of Paris.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let their welcome be thy care good Woolsey.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: It shall my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Spare for no cost, Compton, what news?

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: Ambassadors my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Enough, go give them entertainment lords,
Charles Brandon, hearst thou, give them courtesy
Enough, and state enough, go conduct them.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: I go my lord.

div.stage: Enter Will summers booted and spurved, blowing a horn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How now William, what? post, post, where have you been riding.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Out of my way old Harry, I am all on the spur,
I can tell ye, I have tidings worth telling.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why, where hast thou been:

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Marry I rise early, and ride post to London, to know what news was here at court.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Was that your nearest way William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O ay, the very foot path, but yet I rid the horse ▪ way to here it, I warrant there is never a cundhead keeper in London, but knows what is done in all the courts in Christendom

sp.speaker: Wolsey.
sp.p: And what is the best news there William?

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: Good news for you my lord Cardinal, for one of the old women water-bearers told me for certain, that last Friday all the bells in Rome rang backward, there was a thousand dirges sung, six hundred ave-maries said, every man washed his face in holy water, the people crossing and blessing themselves to send them a new Pope, for the old is gone to purgatory.

sp.speaker: Wolsey:
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay, my lord you'd laugh, if't were so indeed, for everybody thinks if the Pope were dead; you gape for a benefice, but this news my lord is called too good to be true.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But this news came a pace will, that came from Rome to London since Friday last,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: For, 'twas at Billingsgate by Saturday morning, 'twas a full moon, and it came up in a spring tide.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Then you here of the ambassadors that are come.

sp.speaker: Wills.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and that was the cause of my riding to know what they came for, I was told it all at a barber's.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ha, ha, what a fool's this, Jane, and what do they say he comes for, will:

sp.speaker: William:
sp.p: Marry they say he comes to crave thy aid against the great Turk that vows to overrun all France within this fortnight, he's in a terrible rage belike, and they say, the reason is, his old god Mamet that was buried ith' top on's church at Meca, his tomb fell down, and killed a sow and seven pigs, whereupon they think all swine's flesh is new sanctified, and now it is thought the Jews will fall to eating of pork extremely after it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This is strange indeed, but is this all.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
No there is other news that was told me, among the women at a back house, and that is this, they say, the great bell in Glastonbury. Tor has told twice, and that King Arthur, and his knights of the round table that were buried in armour, are alive again, crying saint gorge for England, and mean shortly to conquer Rome,
marry this is thought to be but a moral,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The ambassadors are coming, and hear William see that you be silent, when you see them hear.

sp.speaker: William:
sp.p: I'll be wise and say little I warrant thee, and therefore till I see 'em come, I'll go talk with the Queen; how dost thou lane, sirrah. Harry, she looks very big upon me, but I care not, and she bring thee a young prince, will summer's may haps be his fool, when you two are both dead and 〈◊〉:

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Go to William, how now Jane what groaning,
Gods me thou'st an angry soldiers frown:

sp.speaker: William.
sp.l: I think to Harry, thou hast pressed her often:
I am sure this two years she has served under thy standard.

sp.speaker: Q: lane,
sp.l: Good faith my lord I must entreat your grace
That with your favour I may leave the presence:
I cannot stay to hear this embassage,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: God's holy mother, ladies leave her to her chamber,
Go bid the midwives, and the nurse's v. aight,
Make hole some fierce and take her from the air,
Now Jane God bring me but a chopping boy,
Be but the mother to a prince of Wales
Add a ninth Henry to the English crown,
And thou mak'st full my hopes, fair Queen adieu:
And may heavens helping hand our joys renew:

sp.speaker: Comp:
sp.l: God make your majesty a happy mother,

sp.speaker: Dud:
sp.l: And help you in your weakest passions,
With zealous prayer we all will invocate:
The powers divine for your delivery:

sp.speaker: Q: lane,
sp.l: We thank you all, and in fair interchange
We'll pray for you: now on my my humble knees,
I take my leave of your high majesty,
God send your highness' long and happy reign,
And bless this King dome, and your subjects' lives:
And to your gracious heart all joy restore,
I fear I shall never behold you more,

sp.speaker: King,
sp.l: Do not think so fair Queen, go to thy bed,
Let not my love be so discomforted.

sp.speaker: Wil,
sp.l: No. No, I warrant thee Jane, make haste and dispatch this
That thou mayst have another against next Christmas

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ladies attend her, countess of Salisbury, sister Mary
Who first brings word that Harry hath a son
Shall be rewarded well:

sp.speaker: Will,
sp.p:
Ay, I'll be his surety: but do you hear wenches, she that
brings the first tidings howsoever it fall out lot her be sure to say the child's like the father or else she shall have nothing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Welcome lord Bonnevet, welcome Bishop
What from our brother brings this embassage.

sp.speaker: Bonneuet.
sp.l: Most fair commends great and renowned hen.
We in the person of our lord and King,
Here of your highness, do entreat a league
And to reedify the former peace:
Held betwixt the realms of England and of France,
Of late disordered for some petty wrongs:
And pray your majesty to stay your powers;
Already levied in low Burgundy,
Which to maintain our oaths, shall be engaged,
And to confirm it with more surety,
He craves your 〈◊〉 consent unto his love,
And give the lady Mary for his Queen,
The second sister to your royal self.
So may an heir springing from both your bloods.
Make both realms happy by a lasting league ,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We kindly do receive your master's love,
And yet our grant stands strong unto his suit,
If that no following censure feeble it:
For we herein must take our counsels aid.
But howsoever our answer shall be swift,
Mean time we grant you fair access to woe,
And win her (If you can) to be his Queen.
Ourself will second you. Right welcome both,
Lord Cardinal, these lords shall be your guests,
But let our treasure waste to welcome them:
Banquet them, how they will, what cheer, what sport,
Let them see Harry keeps a kingly court:

sp.speaker: Wolsey.
sp.l: I shall my sovereign.
Ki with draw a while ourselves will follow ye.
Now will are you not deceived in this embassage,
You heard they came for aid against the Turk.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Well then, now I see there is loud lies told in London
But all's on for their comming's to as much purpose as the other:

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: And why I pray,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Why dost thou think thy sister such a fool, to marry such an old dies veneris, he get her with prince? Ay, when either I, or the Cardinal prove Pope, and that will never be, I hope:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How knowest thou him to be old, thou never 〈◊〉 him?

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: No, nor he me, but I saw his picture with nerva tooth ● the head out, and all his beard as well favoured as a white frost, but it is no matter, if he have her, he will die shortly, and then she may help to nury him,

sp.speaker: 1 lad.
sp.l: Run, run, good madam, call the ladies in.
Call for more women's help, the Queen is sick.

sp.speaker: 2 lad
sp.l: For god's love go back again, and warm more clothes,
Oh let the wine be well burned I charge ye.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Ay, in any case, or I cannot drink it, dost thou hear Harry, what a coil they keep: I warrant, these women will drink thee up more wine, with their gossipping, then was spent in all the conduits at thy coronation.

div.stage: Enter lady Mary and the countess of Salisbury.

sp.speaker: King,
sp.l: I is no matter ●ill, how now ladies,

sp.speaker: La: marry,
sp.p: I beseech your grace command the fool forth of the presence,

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Away William you must be gone, here's women's matters in hand

sp.speaker: Will●,
sp.l: Let them speak lo then, I'll not out of the room, sure,

sp.speaker: Count,
sp.l: Come, come let's thrust him out, he'll not stir else:

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: Thrust me, nay and ye go to thrusting, I'll thrust some of you down I warrant ye:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay, go good William:

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: I'll out of their company harry, they will scratch worse than cats, if they catch me, therefore I'll hence and leave them, God boy ladies do you hear madam Mary, you had need to be wary, my news is worth a white-cake, you must play at tennis with old saint Dennis, and your maidenhead must lie at the stake.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ha, ha, the fool tells you true (My gentle sister)
But to our business, how fares my Queen?
How fares my Jane, has she a son for me?
To raise again our kingdom's sovereignty

sp.speaker: Lady Marry,
sp.l: That yet rests doubtful, oh my princely lord.
Your poor distressed Queen lies weak and sick,
And be it son or daughter, dear she buys it,
Even with her dearest life, for one must die:
All women's help is past. Then good my liege,
Resolve it quickly, if the Queen shall live,
the child 〈◊〉 die, or if it life receives,
You must your hapless Queen of life bereave,

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You pierce me with your news, run, send for help.
Spend the revenues of my crown for aid,
To save the life of my beloved Queen:
How happed she is so ill attended on.
That we are put to this extremity,
To save the mother or the child to die.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.l: I beseech your grace resolve immediately,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Immediately (Sayest thou) oh, 'tis no quick resolve
Can give good verdict in so sad a choice:
To lose my Queen, that is my some of bliss,
More virtuous than a thousand kingdoms be;
And should I lose my son (If son it be)
That all my subjects to desire to see.
I lose the hope of this great monarchy.
What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Lady Marry.
sp.l: Remember the Queen my lord:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I not forget her (Sister) oh poor soul,
But I forget thy pain and misery,

sp.speaker: Go,
sp.l: Let the child die; let the mother live,
Heaven's powerful hand may more children give:
Away, and comfort her with our reply,
Harry will have his Queen though thousands die.
I know no issue of her princely womb:
Why then should I prefer't before her life.
Whose death ends all my hopeful loys on earth.
God's will be done, for sure it is his will,
For secret reasons to himself best known:
Perhaps he did mould forth a son for me,
And seeing (That sees all) in his creation,
To be some impotent and coward spirit,
Unlike the figure of his royal father:
Has thus decreed, lest he should blur out fame,
As whilom did the sixth King of my name
Lose all his father (The first Henry) won.
I'll thank the heavens for taking such a son.
Who's within there?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go Compton, bid lord Seimer come to me,
The honoured father of my woeful Queen
Now now what news?

sp.speaker: L. marry.
sp.l: We did deliver what your highness wild,
Which was no sooner by her grace received:
But with the sad report, she seemed as dead,
Which caused us stay, after recovery.
She sent us back t'intreat your majesty,
As ever you did take delight in her,
As you prefer the quiet of her soul,
That now is ready to forsake this life,
As you desire to have the life of one,
She doth entreat your grace that she may die,
Lest both doth perish in this agony:
For to behold the infant suffer death,
Were endless tortures, made to stop her breath,
Then to my lord (Quoth she) thus gently say,
The child is fair, the mother earth and clay,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sad messenger of woe; o my poor Queen,
Canst thou so soon consent to leave this life,
So precious to our soul, so dear to all,
To yield the hopeful issue of thy loins,
To raise our second comfort, well, be it so:
Ill, be it so: stay, I revoke my word,
But that you say helps not, for she must die:
Yet if ye can save both, I'll give my crown:
Nay, all I have, and enter bonds for more,
Which with my conquering sword with fury bent,
I'll purchase in the farthest continent,
Use all your chiefest skill, make haste away,
Whilst we for your success devoutly pray.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: All joy and happiness betide my sovereign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Joy be it good lord Seymer noble father,
Or joy, or grief, thou hast a part in it,
Thou commit to greet us in a doubtful hour,
Thy daughter and my Queen lies now in pain,
And if I lose, Seymer thou canst not gain.

sp.speaker: Sey.
sp.l: Yet comfort, good my liege, this woman's woe,
Why? 'tis as certain to her as her death,
Both given her in her first creation:
It is a sour to sweet, given them at first,
By their first mother, then put sorrow hence:
Your grace, ere long shall see a gallant prince,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be thou a prophet Seymer in thy words,
Thy love some comfort to our hopes affords,
How now.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: My gracious lord, here I present to you,
A goodly son: see here your flesh, your bone,
Look here royal lord, I warrant 'tis your own.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: See here my liege, by the rood a gallant prince,
Ha little cakebread, fore-god a chopping boy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Even now I wept with sorrow, now with joy,
Take that for thy good news, how fares my Queen.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O my good lord, the woeful.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tell no more of woe, speak, doth she live?
What? weep ye all, nay, than my heart misgives,
Resolve me sister, is the news worth hearing.

sp.speaker: L. Marry.
sp.l: Nor worth the telling, royal sovereign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now, by my crown, thou dim'st my royalty,
And with thy cloudy looks eclipsed my joys,
Thy silent eye betrays a ruthful sound,
Stopped in the organs of thy troubled spirit:
Say, is she dead.

sp.speaker: La. Marry.
sp.l: Without offence she is.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Without offence, saist thou, heaven take my soul,
What can be more offensive to my life:
Then sad remembrance of my fair Queen's death,
Thou woeful man, that camest to comfort me:
How shall I ease thy heart's calamity?
That cannot help thyself, how one sad minute
Hath raised a fount of sorrows in his eyes,
And bleared his aged cheeks, yet Seymer see,
She hath left part of herself, a son to me:
To thee a grandchild, unto the land a prince,
The perfect substance of his royal mother,
In whom her memory shall ever live:
Phoenix Jana obit vato Phaenice,
Dolendum secula phaenices nulla ●nlisse dvas.
One phoenix dying, gives another life,
Thus must we flatter our extremest grief.
What day is this.

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: Saint Edward's even my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Prepare for christening, Edward shall be his name,

div.stage: Enter the Cardinal, ambassadors, Bonner and Gardner.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: My lords of France you have had small cheer with us,
But you must pardon us, the times are sad,
And focits not now for mirth and banqueting:
Therefore I pray make your swift return,
Commend me to your King, and kindly tell him,
The English Cardinal will remain his friend,
The lady marry shall be forthwith sent,
And overtake ye ere you reach to Dover:
And for the business that concerns the league,
Urge it no more, but leave it to my care,

sp.speaker: Bone.
sp.l: We thank your grace, my good lord Cardinal,
And so with thankfulness we take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Happily speed my honourable lords,
My heart, I swear, still keeps you company,
Farewell to both, pray your King remember,
My suit betwixt him and the emperor,
We shall be thankful, if they think on us.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: We will be earnest in your cause my lord,
So of your grace we once more take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Again farewell, Bonner conduct them forth,
Now Gardner, what thinkst thou of these times.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, that the leagues confirmed, my gracious lord,
Ill, that I fear the death of good Queen Jane,
Will caute new troubles in our state again.

sp.speaker: Vvool.
sp.l: Why thinkst thou so?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I fear false Luther; doctrines spread so far,
I cast that his highness now unmarried,
Should match amongst that sect of Lutherans,
You saw how soon his majesty was won,
To scorn the Pope, and Rome's religion,
When Queen Anne Bullen wore the diadem.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Gardner 'tis true, so was the rumor spread:
But Wolsey wrought such means she lost her head,
Tush fear not thou whilst Harry's life doth stand,
He shall be King, but we will rule the land.
Bonner come hither, you are our trusty friend:
See that the treasure we have gathered,
the copes, the vestments, and the chalices,
The smoke pence, and the tributary fees,
That English chimneys pay the church of Rome:
Be barrelled close within the inner seller,
We'll send it over shortly to prepare,
Our swift advancement to saint Peter's chair,
Be trusty, and be sure of honours speedily,
The King hath promised at the next election,
Bonner shall have the bishopric of London.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I humbly thank your grace.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: And Gardner shall be lord of Winchester:
Had we our hopes, what shall you not be then,
When we have got the papal diadem.

div.stage: Enter Brandon, Dudley, Gray, Seymer, Compton.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: How now sir William Cumpton, where is the King.

sp.speaker: Cum.
sp.l: His grace is walking in the gallery,
As sad and passionate as ere he was.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: 'Twere good your grace went in to comfort him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Not I lord Dudley, by my George I swear,
Unless his highness first had sent for me,
I will not put my head in such a hazard,
I know his anger, and his spleen too well.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: 'Tis strange, this humour hath his highness held,
Ever since the death of good Queen Jane,
That none dares venture to confer with him.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Here comes the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Bran
sp.p: Ay, and two fools after him, his lordship is well attended still

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Let's win this prelate to salute the King,
It may perhaps work his disgrace with him,

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: How now William, what? are you here to,

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: I my lord, all the fools follow you, I come to bid my cousin patch welcome to the court, and when I come to York house, he'll do as much for me, will ye not patch?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Yes cousin, heigh, da, tere, dedell, day, day.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: What, are you singing sirrah.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I'll make 〈◊〉 cry as fast anon I hold a penny.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Good morrow to your grace my good lord cardinal.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We thank your honour.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What Cumpton, Carew.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Hark, the King calls.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Mother of God, how are we attended on: who weights without.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Go in sir William, and if you find his grace
In any milder temper than he was last night,
Let us have word, and we will visit him.

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: I will my lord.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: What is the occasion, that the Kings so moved.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: His grace hath taken such an inward grief,
With sad remembrance of the Queen that's dead:
That much his highness wrongs his state and person,
Besides in Ireland, do the Burkes rebel,
And stout Percy that disclosed the plot,
Was by the Earl of Kildare late put to death.
And Martin Luther out of Germany.
Has writ a book against his majesty,
For taking part with proud Pope Julius,
Which being spread by him through Christendom,
Hath thus incensed his royal majesty.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Tush, I have news, my lord, to salve that sore,
And make the King more feared through Christendom,
Then ever was his famous ancestors:
Nor can base Luther with his heresies,
Backed by the proudest German potentate,
Heretically blur King Henry's fame:
For honour that he did Pope Julius,
Who in high favour of his majesty,
Hath sent Campeus with a bull from Rome,
To add unto his title this high style:
That he and his fair posterity,
Proclaimed defenders of the faith shall be:
For which intent the holy Cardinals come,
As legates from the imperial court of Rome.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.l: This news, my lord, may something ease his mind,
'Twere good your grace would go and visit him.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: I will, and doubt not but to please him well.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: So, I am glad he's in, and the King be no better pleased than he was at our last parting, he'll make him repent his sauciness.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: How now old William, how chance you go not to the King, and comfort him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
No by’r lady, my lord, I was with him too lately already, his fist is too heavy for a fool to stand under, I went to him last night,
after you had left him, seeing him chase so at Charles, here to make him merry; and he gave me such a box on the ear, that stroke me clean through three chambers, down four pair of stairs, fell o'er five barrels, into the bottom of the seller, and if I had not well liquor myself there, I had never lived after it.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Faith will, I'll give thee a velvet coat, and thou canst but make him merry.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Will ye my lord, and I'll venture another box on the ear but I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Cum.
sp.l: Clear the presence there, the King is coming,
Gods me, my lords, what meant the Cardinal,
So unexpected thus to trouble him.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: Is the King moved at it.

sp.speaker: Cumpt.
sp.l: Judge by his countenance, see he comes.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I'll not endure the storm.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Run fool your master will be felled else.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did we not charge that none should trouble us,
Presumptuous priest, proud prelate as thou art,
How comes it you are grown so saucy sir,
Thus to presume upon our patience,
And cross our royal thought disturbed and vexed,
By all your negligence in our estate,
Of us and of our country's happiness.

sp.speaker: Vvool.
sp.l: My gracious lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fawning beast stand back:
Or by my crown, I'll foot thee to the earth,
Where's Brandon, Surrey, Seymer, grey,
Where is your counsel now, oh now ye crouch,
And stand like pictures at our presence door,
Call in our guard, and bear them to the tower,
Mother of God, I'll have the traitor's heads,
Go hale them to the block, up, up, stand up,
I'll make you know your duties to our state,
Am I a cypher, is my sight grown stale,
Am I not Harry, am I not England's King, ha.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: So la, now the watch words given, nay and he once cry ha, ne'er a man in the court dare for his head speak again, lie close cousin Patch.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: I'll not come near him cousin, has almost killed me with his countenance.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We have been too familiar, now I see,
And you may dally with our majesty:
Where are my pages there.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Truss sirrah, none to put my garter on,
Give me some wine, here stuff a the tother side,
Proud Cardinal who followed our affairs in Italy,
That we that honoured so Pope Julius,
By dedicating books at thy request,
Against that upstart sect of Lutherans,
Should by that heretic be banded thus,
But by my George, I swear, if Henry live,
I'll hunt base Luther through all Germany,
And pull those seven electors on their knees:
If they but back him against our dignities.
Base slave tie soft, thou hur'st my leg,
And now in Ireland the Burkkes rebel,
And with his stubborn kerns makes hourly roads,
To burn the borders of the English pale,
And which of all your counsels helps us now.

sp.speaker: Cumpt.
sp.l: Here's wine, my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Drink, and be damned, I cry thee mercy Cumpton,
What the devil meantst thou to come behind me so,
I did mistake, I'll make thee amends for it,
By holy Paul, I am so crossed and vexed,
I knew not what I did, and here at home,
Such careful statesmen do attend us,
And looks so wisely to our common weal,
That we have ill May-day's, and riots made:
For lawless rebels do disturb our state,
Twelve times this term, have we in person sat,
Both in the star chamber, and chancery courts,
To hear our subjects' suits determined:
Yet 'tis your office Wolsey, but all of you
May make a packhorse of King Henry now:
Well, what would ye say.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Nothing that might displease your majesty,
I have a message from the Pope to you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then keep it still, we will not hear it yet,
get all of you away, avoid our presence
We cannot yet command our patience,
Reach me a chair.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Now will, or never, make the King but smile,
And with thy mirthful toys allay his spleen,
That we his counsel, may confer with him,
And by my honour, I'll reward thee well,
Too him good will.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Not too fast, I pray, least will Sommers here be seen again, I know his qualities as well as the best an ye: for ever when he's angry, and nobody dare speak to him, ye thrust me in by the head and shoulders, and then we fall to buffets, but I know who has the worst aunt: but go, my lord, stand aside, and stir not till I call ye, let my cousin patch and I alone, and he go to boxing, we'll fall both upon him, that's certain: but and the worst come, be sure the Cardinal's fool shall pay fort.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Use your best skill, good William, I'll not be seen, unless I see him smile.

sp.speaker: William
sp.p: Where art thou cousin, alas poor fool, he's crept under the table, up cousin, fear nothing, the storms past, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.l: Is the King gone, cousin?

sp.speaker: William
sp.l: No, no, 〈◊〉 he sits, we are all friends now,
sp.p: The lords are gone to dinner, and thou and I must wait at the King's table.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Not I by’r lady, I would not wait upon such a lord, for all the livings in the land, I thought he would have killed my lord Cardinal, he looked so terribly.

sp.speaker: William
sp.p: Foe, he did but jest with him, but I'll tell the cousin the rarest trick to be revenged as't passes, and I'll give thee this fine silk point and thou'lt do it.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: O brave, o brave, give me it cousin, and I'll do whatsoe'er 'tis.

sp.speaker: William
sp.p: I'll stand behind the post here, and thou shalt go softly stealing behind him, as he sits reading yonder, and when thou com'st 〈◊〉 to him, cryboh, and we'll scar him so, he shall not tell where to rest him.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: But will he not be angry?

sp.speaker: William
sp.p:
No, no, for then I'll show myself, and after he sees who 'tis he'll
la●e and be as merry as a mag pie, and though't be a 〈◊〉 man by it, for all the house shall see him hug thee in his arms, ● dandle thee up and down with hand and foot an thou wert a football,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: O fine come cousin, give me the pint first, and I'll roar so loud that I'll make him believe that the duels come.

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: So do and fear nothing, for an thou wert the devil himself, he'll conjure thee I warrant thee, I would not have such a conjuring for twenty crowns: but when he has made way, I'll make him merry enough, I doubt it not, so so now cousin look to your coxcomb:

sp.speaker: Page:
sp.l: Boe.

sp.speaker: I'll:
sp.l: Mother of god what's that.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Boe.

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: Out ass take that and tumble at my feet.
For thus I'll spurn thee up an down the house:

sp.speaker: Pach:
sp.l: Help cousin help:

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.l: No cousin now he's coniuring. I dare not come near him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who set this natural ●eere to trouble me.

sp.speaker: En, Comp:
sp.p: Who's that stands laughing there, the fool, ha, ha, where's Compton. Mother a god I have found his drift, 'tis the craftiest old villain in Christendom, mark good sir William, because the fool durst not come near himself, seeing our anger, sent this silly ass, that we might wreak our royal spleen on him: whilst he stands laughing to behold the left, byth' blessed la (Copton) I'll not leave the fool, to gain a million, he contents me so, come hither will,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I'll know whether ye have done knocking first, my cousin patch looks pitifully, ye had best be friends with us I can tell you, we'll scare ye out of your skin else

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: Alas, poor patch hold 〈◊〉 there's an angel to buy you points.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: La cousin, did not I say he'll make much on ye,

sp.speaker: Pach:
sp.l: I cousin but has made such a singing in my head
I cannot see where I am.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: All the better cousin and your head fall a singing, your feet may fall a dancing and so save charges to the piper:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Will Sommers, prithee tell me why didst thou send him first.

sp.speaker: Vvil.
sp.p: Because I'll have him have the first fruits of thy fury. I know how the matter stood with the next that disturbed thee, therefore I kept ith' rearward, that if the battle grew too hot, I might run presently,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But wherefore came ye.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
To make thee leave thy melancholy and turn merry man again, thou hast made all the court in such a pitiful case as passes,
the lords has attended here this ●oure days, and none dares speak to thee, but thou art ready to chop of their heads sort: and now I seeing what a fretting fury thou continuest in, and every one said 'twould kill thee if thou keepest it, pulled e'en up my heart, and vowed to lose my head, but I'll make thee leave it,

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.l: Well William I am beholding to ye.
Ye shall have a new coat and a cap for this.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Nay then, I shall have two new coats and cap pes, for Charles Brandon promised me one before, to perform this enterprise:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He shall keep his word will, go call him in,
Call in the lords tell them our spleen is calmed:
Mother a God we must give way to wrath.
That chafes our royal blood with anger thus:
And use some mirth I see to comfort us.
Draw near us lords, Charles Brandon lift to me:
Will Sommers here must have a coat of you,
But patch has earned it dearest where's the fool?

sp.speaker: Vvil.
sp.l: He's enne creeping as ne'er the door as he can,
He'll fain begone I see, and he could get out,
Wouldest thou not cousin?

sp.speaker: Pach:
sp.l: Yes cousin Will. I'd fain be walking, I am afraid,
I am not as I should be:

sp.speaker: Vvil.
sp.p: Come, I'll help thee out then, dost thou hear my lord Cardinal, your fool is in a pitiful taking, he smells terribly.

sp.speaker: Wools:
sp.l: You are too crafty for him William,

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: So is he woolsey credit me.

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.p: I think so my lord, as long as will live, the Cardinal's fool must give way to the King's fool:

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Well sir be quiet, and my reverent lords,
I thank you for your patient suffering,
We were disturbed in our thoughts we swear,
We now entreat you speak and we will hear,

sp.speaker: Wools.
sp.l: Then may it please your sacred majesty,

sp.speaker: Campe.
sp.l: Legate to his holiness,
Attends with letters from the court of Rome.

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: Let him draw near, we'll give him audience,

sp.speaker: Dudley:
sp.l: And grey attend the Cardinal,
And bring

sp.speaker: Campeu:
sp.l: To our presence here:

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Grey, we go my lord:

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: Brandon and Seymer, place yourselves by us,
To hear this message from his holiness,
You reverent princes pillars of the church:
Legates, Apostolic, how fares the Pope,

sp.speaker: Campeus,
sp.l: In health great King and from his sacred lips:
I bring a blessing apostolical.
To English Henry and his subjects all:
And more to manifest his love to thee,
The prop and pillar of the church's peace:
And gratify thy love made plain to him,
In learned books 'gainst Luther's heresy,
He sends me thus to greet thy majesty:
With style and titles of high dignity,
Command the heralds and the trumpets forth:

sp.speaker: Semer:
sp.l: Gentlemen dispatch and call them in:

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.l: Lord bless us, what's here to do now,

sp.speaker: Campe,
sp.l: Receive this bull sent from his holiness.
For confirmation of his dignity
To thee, and to thy fair posterity.

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: 'Tis well the Kings a widower, and he had put forth your bull with his horns forward, I'd have marred your message. I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Peace

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.l: Heralds attend him:

sp.speaker: Campe:
sp.l: Trumpets prepare whilst we allowed pronounce
This sacred message from his holiness,
And in his reverent name I hear proclaim
Henry the eight by the grace of God,
King of England, France and Ireland ▪
And to this title, from the Pope we give:
Defender of the faith, in peace to live:

sp.speaker: Vvools,
sp.l: Sound trumpets, and God save the King.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: We thank his holiness for this princely favour,
Receiving it with thanks and reverence:
In which whilst we have life, his grace shall see,
Our sword defender of the faith shall be,
Go one of you salute the mayor of London,
Bid him with heralds and with trumpets sound,
Proclaim our titles through his government,
Go grey, see it done, attend him fellows:

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.l: I go my lord, trumpets follow me,

sp.speaker: King,
sp.l: What more lord legate doth his holiness will?

sp.speaker: Campe:
sp.l: That Henry joining with the Christian Kings
Of France and Spain, Denmark and Portugal
Would send an army to assail the Turk,
That now invades with war the I'll of Rhodes,
Or send twelve thousand pound to be disposed,
As his holiness thinks best for their relief .

sp.speaker: Wils:
sp.p: I thought so, I knew 'twould be a monnie matter, when all's done, now thou'rt defender of the faith, the Pope will have thee defend every thing himself and all.

sp.speaker: King,
sp.l: Take hence the fool.

sp.speaker: Vvil:
sp.p: Ay, when can ye tell? dost thou think any oath lords will take the fool, none here, I warrant, except the Cardinals.

sp.speaker: King,
sp.p: What a knavish fools this, lords you must bear with him come hither will, what saist thou to this new title given us by the Pope, speak, is't not rare?

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: I know not how rare it is, but I know how dear 'twill be, for I perceive 'twill cost thee twelve thousand 'Pounds, at least, besides the cardinals cost in comming.

sp.speaker: King,
sp.p: All these nothing; the title of defender of the faith is worth ye, twice as much, say, is it not.

sp.speaker: Vvyll:
sp.p: No by my troth, dost hear old Harry; I am sure, the true faith is able to defend itself without thee, and as for the Pope's faith (Good faith's) not worth a farthing, and therefore give him not a penny.

sp.speaker: K,
sp.p: Go too 〈◊〉 meddle not you with the Pope's matters:

sp.speaker: Vv:
sp.p: Let him not meddle with thy matters then, for, and he meddle with thee, he middle with him that's certain and so farewell, I'll go and meet my little young master prince Edward, they say he comes to court tonight , I'll to horseback, prithee Harry send one to hold my stirrup: shall I tell the prince what the Pope has done.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I and thou wilt will, he shall be defender of the faith too● one day.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: No, and he and I can defend ourselves we care not,
For we are sure the faith can.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lord legate, so we reverence Rome and you,
As nothing you demand, shall be denied:
The Turk will we expel from Christendom,
Sending stout soldiers to his holiness,
And money to relieve distressed Rhodes :
So if you please, pass in to banqueting,
Go lords attend them, Brandon and Compton stay,
We have some business to confer upon.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: We take our leave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Most hearty welcome to my reverent lords.
So, now to our business, 〈◊〉,
Hear ye no tidings from our sister Mary,
Since her arrival in the realm of France?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.l: Thus much we heard my lord, at Cales met her
The youthful dolphin, and the peers of France:
And bravely brought her to the King at towers,
Where he both married her, and crowned her Queen

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis well, but Brandon and
Compion list to me,
I must employ your aid and secrecy,
This night we mean in some disguised shape;
To visit London, and to walk the round,
Pass through their watches, and observe the care
And special diligence to keep our peace.
They say night-walkers, hourly pass the streets,
Committing the●, and hated sacrilege:
And slightly pass unstaid, or unpunished,
Go Compton, go, and get me some disguise,
This night we'll see our city's government:
Brandon, do you attend at Baynard's. Castio,
Compton shall go disguised along with me,
Our swords and bucklers shall conduct us safe,
But if we catch a knock to quit our pain,
We'll put it up, and buy us home again.

div.stage: Enter the constable and watch, Prichall the cobbler, being one bearing a lantern.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.l: Come neighbours, we have a straight command.
Our watches be severely looked into:
Much theft and murder was committed lately,
There are two strangers, merchants of the stillyard
Cruelly slain, found floating on the temmes:
And greatly are stews had in suspect,
As places fitting for no better use,
Therefore be careful and examine all,
Perhaps we may attach the murderer.

sp.speaker: 1 watch
sp.p: Nay I assure ye master constable, those stew houses are places of much slaughter and redemption and many cruel deeds of equity and wickedness are committed there, for divers good men lose both their money and their computation by them, I abjure ye; how say you neighbour Prichall?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Neighbour capcase, I know you're a man of courage, and for the merry cobbler of lune street, though I sit as low as saint faithes, I can look as high as Pa●les': I have in my days walked to the stew as as well as my neighbours, but if the mad wenches fall to burdening once, and cast men into the Thames, I have done with them, there's no dealing, if they carry fire in one hand, and water ith' tother.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Well masters we are now placest about the King's business.
And I know ye all sufficient in the knowledge of it,
I need not to repeat your charge again:
Good neighbours, use your greatest care I pray,
And if unruly persons trouble ye,
Call and I'll come: so ●yrs good-night.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: Godyegodnight and twenty sir, I warrant ye, ye need not reconcile to our charge, vor some on us has discharged the place this forty year I am sure. Neighbours what think you best to be done?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Every man according to his calling neighbour, if the enemy come, here lies my town of garrison, I set on him as I set on a patch, if he tread on this side, I underlay him on this side, or prick him through both sides, I yerk him, and trick him, pare him and piece him, then hang him up beth heels till Sunday.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: How say ye, by my faith neighbour Prichall ye speak to the purpose, for indeed neighbours, every sensible watchman is to seek the best reformation to his own destruction.

sp.speaker: 2 Wat.
sp.p: But what think ye neighbours, if every man take a nap now, ith' fore hand ith' night, and go to bed afterwards.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: That were not a miss neither, but and you'll take but every man his pot first, you'll sleep like the man ith' moon i'faith.
Do ye think neighbour, there is a man ith' moon?

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: I assure ye in a clear day, I have seen't at midnight.

sp.speaker: 2 Wat.
sp.p: Of what occupation is he trow●

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Some thinks he's a shepherd, because on's dog, some says he's a baker going to heat his oven with a bavin at's back, but the plain truth is, I think he was a cobbler, for ye know what the song says, I see a man ith' moon, fie man, fie, I see a man ith' moon, clouting saint Peter's shoes, and so by this reason, he should be a cobbler.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: By my fekins he saith true, alas, alas, goodman dormouse hath even given up the ghost already, us an honest quiet soul I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: It behoves us all to be so how do ye neighbour Darmonse?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Godspeed ye, godspeed ye, nay and ye go a godssleepie, name, I have nothing to say to ye.
Law ye, his minds on's business, though he be ne'er so

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Come let's all join with him and steal a nap, every man masters to his several stall.
Agreed, goodnight good neighbours.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p: Nay, let's take no leave, I'll but wink a while, and see you again. ●ward●

div.stage: Enter King, and Compton, with bills on his back.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come sir William,
We may now stand upon our guard you see,
The watch has given us leave to arm ourselves,
They fear no danger, for they sleep secure:
Go carry those bills we took to Baynard's castle,
And bid Charles Brandon to disguise himself,
And meet me presently at grace church corner,
We will attempt to pass through all the watches,
And so I take's will be an easy task,
Therefore make haste.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: I will my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The watchword if I chance to send to ye,
Is the great stag of Baydon, so my name shall be.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Enough, we'll think on it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: So, now we'll forward, soft yonder's light,
I and a watch, and all asleep by’r lady:
These are good peaceable subjects, here's none
Beckons to any, all may pass in peace: ho sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Stand, who goes there?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good fellow. Stands a heinous word the Kings
High way you have been at noddy, I see.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Ay, and the first card comes to my hand's a knave.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am a coatercard indeed.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Then thou must needs be a knave, for art neither King nor Queen, (I am sure) but whether goest thou?.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: About a little business that I have in hand.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Then good night, prithee trouble me no longer.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why this is easy enough, here's passage at pleasure,
What wretch so wicked, would not give fair words
After the foulest fact of villainy?
That may escape unseen so easily,
Or what should let him that is so resolved
To murder, rapine, theft, or sacrilege:
I see the city are the sleepy heads,
to do it, and pass thus unexamined.
Fond heedless men, what boots it for a King,
To toil himself in this high state affairs,
To summon parliaments, and call together
The wise●● heads of all his provinces:
Making statutes for his subjects' peace,
That thus neglecting them, their woes increase.
Well, we'll further on, soft here comes one,
I'll stay and see, how he escapes the watch.

sp.speaker: Black. Vvill.
sp.p: So, how I am got within the city, I am as safe as in a sanctuarieat is a hard world, when black will, for a venture of five pound, must commit such petty robberies at Mile-end, but the plain truth is, the stews from whence I had my quartaridgeas now grown too hot for me: there's some suspection of a murder lately done upon two merchants of the stillyard, which indeed as far as some five or six stabs comes too, I confess I had a hand in. But mum-budget, all the dogs in the town must not bark at it. I must withdraw awhile till the heat ●ee o'er, remove my lodging, and live upon dark nights and 〈◊〉 mornings. Now let me them see, the strongest watch in London intercept my passage.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Such a fellow would I fain meet withal:
Well overtaken sir.

sp.speaker: Black Vvill.
sp.l: 'Sblood 〈◊〉 before me sir:
What a devil art thou?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A man at least.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: And art thou valiant?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I carry a sword and a bucklerye see.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: A sword and a buckler, and know not me, not black will?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No trust me.

sp.speaker: Black Will.
sp.p:
Slave, than thou art neither traveller, nor purse-taker: for I tell thee, black will is known and feared though the seventeen 〈◊〉 there's not a sword
and buckler man in England nor Europe, but has had a taste of my manhood. I am tole-free in all cities, and the suburbs about them: this is my sconce, my castle, my citadel, and but King Harry, God bless his majesty, I fear not the proudest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O ves, some of his guard.

sp.speaker: Black Vvil.
sp.p: Let his guard eats beef and be thankful, give me a man will cover himself with his buckler, and not budge and the devil come.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: methinks thou wert better live at court as I do, King Harry loves a man, I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Black Will.
sp.p: Would thou and all the men he keeps were hanged, and ye love not him then: but I will not change my revenues for all his guards wages.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hast thou such store of living?

sp.speaker: Black william
sp.l: Art thou a good fellow?
May I speak freely, and wilt not tell the King on't?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Keep thine own counsel, and fear not,
sp.p: For of my faith the King shall know no more for me, than thou tellst him.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: And I tell him any thing let him hang me: but for thyself, I think if a fat purse come ith' way, thou wouldst not refuse it. Therefore leave the court and shark with me, I tell thee, I am chief commander of all the stews, there's not a whore shifts a smock but by my privilege, nor opens her shop before I have my weekly tribute: and to assure thee my valour carries credit with it, do but walk with me through the streets of London, and let me see the proudest watch disturb us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I shall be glad of your conduct sir.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: Follow me then, and I'll tell thee more.

sp.speaker: 1 watch
sp.l: Stand, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Blac.
sp.l: A good fellow: come close, regard them not.

sp.speaker: 2. watch
sp.l: How shall we know thee to be a good fellow?

sp.speaker: Black Vvill.
sp.l: My names black will.

sp.speaker: 1. watch
sp.p: O, God give ye good night, good master black William.

sp.speaker: 2. watch
sp.l: God boy sir, God boy,
I am glad we are so well rid on him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: La sir, you see here's egress enough,
Now follow me, and you shall see we'll have regress back again,

sp.speaker: 1. watch
sp.l: Ho comes there?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Come afore the constable.
Will what have ye forgotten me so soon? 'tis I.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.l: O, 'tis m. black William,
God bless ye sir, God bless ye.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: How lik'st thou now?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Faith excellent: but prithee tell me, dost thou face the world with thy manhood, that thus they fear thee, or art thou truly valiant?

sp.speaker: Black Vvill.
sp.p: Sfoot, dost thou doubt of my manhood? Nay then defend yourself, I'll give you a try all presently, betake ye to your tools sir, I'll teach ye to stand upon intergatories.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I am for ye, there's ne'er a man the King keeps shall refuse ye: but tell me, wilt thou keep the King's act for fighting.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.p: As ye please sir: yet because thou'rt his man, I'll observe it, and neither thrust nor strike beneath the knee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am pleased, have at you sir.

sp.speaker: 1. watch
sp.p: Help neighbours, oh take ye to your brown bills, call up the constable, here's a piece of chance-medley ready to be committed: set on goodman Sprichall.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I'll firk them a both sides, lie close neighbour dormouse, keep the King's peace, I charge ye, help m. Constable.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Keep the peace, or strike them down.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: 'Sounds, I am hurt, hold I say.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.p: Let them not pass neighbours, here's bloodshed drawn upon one of the King's officers.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Take away their weapons, and since you are so hot, I'll set you where you shall be cool enough.

sp.speaker: Black ●il
sp.p: 'Sounds the moons a wayning harlot, with the glimpse of her light I lost his point, and mistook my ward, had ne'er brought my blood else.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Pray sir what are you?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am the King's man sir, and of his guard.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: More shame you should so much forget yourself ▪
For as I take't, 'tis parcel of your oath,
As well to keep his peace, as guard his person:
And if a constable be not present by,
You may as well as he, his place supply:
And seeing ye so neglect your oath and duty,
Go bear them to the counter presently,
There shall ye answer for these misdemeanours.

sp.speaker: 2. Wat.
sp.l: Has broke my head sir, and furthermore it bleeds.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Away with them both, they shall pay thee well ere they come forth, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I beesech ye sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Never entreat man, we shall have bail I doubt it not, but master constable, I hope you'll do me this favour, to let one of your watchmen go of an arrant for me, if I pay him?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: With all my heart sir, here's one shall go.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Hold thee good fellow, here's an angel for thee, go thy way to Baynard's castle, and ask for one Brandon, he serves the Duke of Suffolk, and tell him his bedfellow, or the great stag of Baydon this night is clapteth counter, and bid him come speak with me. Come constable let's go, sirrah make haste.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I warrant you sir, and this be all, I'd have done it for half the money: well, I must inquire for one Brandon, and tell him the great stag of B●yd●● i● ith' counter, by’r lady I doubt they be both crafty knaves, and this is some watchword between them: beth mass I doubt he ne'er come well by his money, he's so liberal, well I'll forward.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.l: Sir William, are you sure it was at graces-church
His majesty appointed we should meet him?
We have been there and missed him, what think ye sir?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Good faith I know not.
His highness is too venturous bold, my lord
I know he will forsake himself in this,
Opposing still against a world of odds.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Good faith 'tis true: but soft here comes one,
How now good fellow, whether goest thou?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: It lies in my authority sir,
To ask you that question.
For I am one of the King's watch, I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Then perhaps thou canst tell us some tidings:
sp.p: Didst thou not see a good lusty tall big set man, pass through your watch tonight ?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Yes sir, there was such a man came to our watch to tonight , but none that passed through, for he behaved himself so, that he was laid hold on quickly, and now he is forth coming in the counter.

sp.speaker: Brandon.
sp.p: And whither art thou going?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Faith sir, has given me an angel, to do an errand for him at Baynard's castle, to one Brandon, that serves the Duke of Suffolk: he says he is his bedfellow, and I must tell him, the great stag of Baydon, is ith' counter.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: If thine errand be to Brandon, I can save thee a labour, for I am the man thou look'st for, we have been seeking him almost all this night: hold thee there's an angel for thy news, I'll bail him I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I thank you sir: but he's not so soon bailed, as you think for, there's two of the King's watch has their heads broke, and that must be answered for, but all's won to me, let them shuffle as they will, the angels has flown about tonight , and two gulls are light into my hands, and these I'll keep, let him get out as he can.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ho porter, who's without there?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: What's the matter now? will ye not go to bed tonight ?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No trust me, 'twill be morning presently,
And I have hope I shall be bailed ere then:
sp.p: I prithee if thou canst, entreat some of the prisoners to keepe me company a pair of hours, or so: and we'll spend them: i'the rouse of healths, and all shall be my cost.
sp.l: Say wilt thou pleasure me?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: If that will pleasure ye sir, ye shall not want for company, here's I now that can tend it, they have hunger and ease enough at all times.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The●es a couple of gentlemen in the next room, I prithee let them come in, and there's an Harry sovereign for thee.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: I thank you sir, I am as much beholding to you, as to King Harry for it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ay, I assure thee thou art.
Well m. Constable, you have made the counter
This night, the royal court of England's King:
And by my crown I swear, I would not for ▪
A thousand pound 'twere otherwise.
The officers in cities, now I see,
Are like an orchard set with several trees,
Where one must cherish one, rebuke the other:
And in this wretched counters I perceive,
Money plays fast and loose, purchases favour,
And without that, naught but misery.
A poor gentleman hath made complaint to me,,
I am undone (Quoth he) and kept in prison,
For one of your fellows that serves the King,
Being bound for him, and he neglecting me.
Hath brought me to this woe and misery.
Another citizen there is, complains
Of one belonging to the Cardinal●,
That in his master's name hath taken up
Commodities, valued at a thousand pound:
The payment being deferred hath caused him break,
And so is quite undone. Thus Kings and lords I see,
Are oft abused by servant's treachery.
But whist a while, here comes my fellow prisoners.

sp.speaker: 1. Prisoner.
sp.p: Where's this bully Grig, this lad of life, that will scour the counter with right renish tonight ? O sir you are welcome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I thank ye sir, nay we'll be as great as our word, I assure ye. Here porter, there's money, fetch wine I prithee: gentlemen you cannot be merry in this melancholy place; but here's a lad has his heart as light as his purse. Sirrah, thou art some mad slave I think, a regular companion: won that that uses to walk a nights, or so. Art thou not?

sp.speaker: 1. Pri.
sp.l: Hark ethen ear, thou'rt a good fellow.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am right born I assure thee.

sp.speaker: 1. Pri.
sp.l: King Harry loves a man, and thou a woman:
Shall I teach thee some wit?
And tell thee why I met thee here?
I went and set my limb-twigs, and I think
I got some hundred pound,
By a crooked measure at coo●e park:
And now seeing there was watch laid,
And much search for suspicious persons:
I got won as honest as myself to arrest me,
By a contrary name, and lay me ith' counter,
And here I know they'll ne'er seek me,
And so when the heats o'er, I am at liberty,
And mean to spend my crowns lustily:
How lik'st thou this my bully?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: An excellent policy.

sp.speaker: 1. Pri.
sp.l: But mum, no words: use it for yourself, or so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: O sir, fear it not, be merry gentlemen: is not this wine come yet? God's me, forget our chief ge●st, where's my sword and buckler-man? where's black will? how now man, melancholy? let not a little wipe make us enemies, clap hands, and be friends.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: My bloods up still.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When 'tis at highest 'twill fall again, come hands, hands.

sp.speaker: Black Wil.
sp.p: I'll shake hands with thee, because thou carriest a sword and buckler, yet thou'rt not right cavalier, thou knowest not how to use them, thou'st a heavy arm.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I a good smart stroke.

sp.speaker: Vvil●.
sp.p: Thou cutst my head indeed, but 'twas no play, thou layest open enough, I could have entered at my pleasure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay I have stout guard I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Childish to a man of valour, when thou shouldst have born thy buckler here, thou lettest it fall to thy knee, thou gavest me a wipe, but 'twas mere chance: but had we not been parted, I had taught ye a little school play I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Brandon.
sp.l: What ho, porter: who keeps the gates there?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.l: Who knocks so fast?

sp.speaker: Compt.
sp.l: Stand by sirrah.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Keep back I say, whither will ye press amongst the prisoners?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Sirrah to the court, and we must in.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: Why sir, the courts not kept ith' counter today.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Yes when the King is there ▪
All happiness betide our sovereign.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: 'Sounds King Harry.

sp.speaker: 1. Pri.
sp.l: Lord I beseech thee no.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We all entreat your grace to pardon us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Stand up good men: beshrew ye Brandon for discovering us, we shall not spend our time so well this month: but there's no remedy now, the worst is this,
sp.l: The court good fellows must be removed the sooner,
Ye all are courtiers yet. Nay, nay, come forward,
Even now you know we were more familiar:
You see policies holds not always currant,
I am found out, and so I think will you be:
Go porter let him be removed to Newgate
This place I see is too secure for him:
We'll send you further word for his bestowin.

sp.speaker: 1. Pri
sp.l: I beseech your grace.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: There's no grace in thee, nor ●one for thee:
Go, away with him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: 'Sounds I shall to Tyburne presently.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Gentlemen, you that have been wronged by my servants and the Cardinals, shall give me nearer notes of it,
sp.l: Both what they are, and how much debt they owe ye:
Send your petitions to the court to me.
And doubt not but you shall have remedy:
There's forty angels, drink to King Harry's health,
And think withal, much wrong Kings men may do:
The which their masters never consent unto.

sp.speaker: 2 Pris.
sp.l: God bless your majesty with happy life;
That thus respect; your woeful subjects grief,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where 〈◊〉 Will, nay come nearer man,
I came nearer you, though ye mislikte my play.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: Beth lord, your Majesty's the best sword and buckler man in Europe, ye lie as close to your wards, carry your point as fair, that no fencer comes neere ye for gallant fence-play.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay now ye flatter me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Fore-god ye broke my head most gallantly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I but 'twas but by chance ye know, but now your heads broke, you look for a plaster I am sure.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And your grace will give me leave, I'll put it up and go my ways presently.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay soft sir, the keeper will deny ye that privilege, come hither sirrah, because ye shall know King Harry loves a man, and I perceive there's some mettle in thee, there's 〈…〉 angels for thee, marry it shall be to keep ye in prison still, till we have further use for ye. If ye can break through watches with egress and regress so valiantly, ye shall do't amongst your country's enemies.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: The wars sweet King, 'tis my delight, my desire, my chair of state ▪ create me but a tattered corporal, and give me some pre-eminence over the vulgar hotshots, and I beat them not forward to as brave attempts, and march myself i th' vanguard ▪ as ere carried against a castle wall, break my head in two places more, and consume me with the mouth of a double culvering, I'll live and die with thee sweet King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Twill be your best course sir, go take him in,
When we have need of men, we'll send for him.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.l: God bless your majesty, I'll go drink to your health.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Begun: sir, keeper I thank you for our lodging,
nay indeed I do, I know had ye known us, it had been better,
Pray tell the constable that brought us hither,
We thank him, and commend his faithful service,
Gentlemen let's hear from you, and so good morrow,
Keeper, there's for my fees, discharge the offices:
And give them charge that none discover us,
Till we are passed the city: in this disguise we came.
We'll keep us still, and so depart again.
Once more good morrow, you may now report,
Your connter was one night King Henry's court.
Away and leave us, Brandon what further news?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: The old King of France is dead my liege,
And left your sister Mary a young widow.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: God forbid man, what not so soon I hope,
She has not yet been married forty days:
Is this news certain?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Most true my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Alas poor Mary, so soon a widow,
Before thy wedding robes be half worn out:
We must then prepare black funeral garments too,
Well, we'll have her home, the league is broke:
And we'll not trust her safety with the French.
Charles Brandon ▪ you shall go to France for her,
See that your train be richly furnished,
And if the daring French, brave thee in attempts
Of honour, barriers, tilt, and and tournament:
So to retain her, bore thee like thyself,
An English man, dreadless of the proudest:
And highly scorning lowly hardiness

sp.speaker: 〈◊〉 Bran.
sp.l: I shall my sovereign, and in her honour,
I'll cast a challenge through all the court:
And dare the proudest peer in France for her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Commend me to the lady Catherine Parry,
Give her this ring, tell her on Sunday next
She shall be Queen, and crowned at Westminster:
And Anne of Cleve shall be sent home again:
Come sirs, we'll leave the city, and the counter now,
The day begins to break, let's hie to court.
And once a quarter we desire such sport.

div.stage: Enter the Cardinal reading a letter, 〈◊〉 is his Bishop's r●●bes.

sp.speaker: Vv●l.
sp.l: My reverent lord of London,
Our trusty friend, the King of France is dead,
And in his death, our hopes are hindered:
The emperor too, mislikes his praises,
But we shall cross him fort I doubt it not:
And tread upon his pomp imperial,
That thus hath wronged the English Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Your grace's letters by Campeus sent,
I doubt not but shall work your full content.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: I that must be our safest way to work,
Money will make us men, when men stand out:
The bastard Fredericks to attain the place,
Hath made an offer to the Cardinals,
Of threescore thousand pound, which we will pay,
Three times thrice double, ere we lose the day.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Come cousin William, I'll bring ye to my lord Cardinal presently.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I thank ye cousin, and when you come to the court, I'll bring you to the King again, ye know cousin, he gave ye an angel.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: I but he gave me such a blow o'th' ear for it, as I care not for coming in's sight again while I live.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: How now patch, who have you got there? what will Summer's welcome good William.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I thank your grace, I hard say your lordship had made two new lords here, and so the two old fools are come to wait on them.

sp.speaker: B●n.
sp.l: We thank ye 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Patch
sp.p:
Your lordship will be well guarded, we follow ●e,
the King's fool, and the Cardinals, and we are no small fools I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: No indeed, my cousin patch here is something too square to be set on your shoe, marry and you'll wear him on your shoulder, the fool shall ride ye.

sp.speaker: Vv●l.
sp.p: A shrewd fool Bonner, come hither William, I have a quarrel to you since our last rhyming.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.l: About your fair leman at Charlton my lord, I remember.

sp.speaker: B●●.
sp.l: You speak plain William.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ye never knew fool a flatterer I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: W●l.
sp.l: Well Will, I'll try your rhyming wits once more,
What say you to this?
The bells hang high, and loud they cry, what do they speak?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: If you should die, there's none would cry, though your neck should break.

sp.speaker: W●l.
sp.p: You are something bitter William: but come on, once more I am for ye. A rod in school, a whip for a fool, is always in season.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A halter and a rope, for him that would be Pope,
Against all right and reason.

sp.speaker: W●l.
sp.p: He●s too hard for me still, I'll give him over, come tell me Wul, what's the news at court?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Marry my lord, they say the King must be married this morning.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: Married will, to whom I prithee?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why to my lady Catherine Parry, I was once by, when he was wooing on her, and then I doubted they would go together shortly.

sp.speaker: W●l.
sp.l: Holy saint Peter shield his majesty,
She is the hope of 〈◊〉 heresy:
If she be Queen, the Protestants will swell,
And Cranmer, tutor to the prince of Wales,
Will boldly speak 'gainst Rome's religion ▪
But Bishops we'll to court immediately,
And plot the downfall of these Lutherans:
You two are tutors to the princes Mary,
still ply her to the 〈◊〉 obedience,
And make her hate the name of protestant;
I do suspect that Latimer and 〈◊〉
Chief teachers of the fair 〈◊〉,
Are not sound Catholics, nor friends to 〈◊〉
It it be so, we'll soon remove them all .
'Tis better they should die, than thousands fall.
Come follow us. Ma●it, w●l, and patch.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: Your lords mad, till he be at the wedding, 'twas marvel the King stole it so secretly and ner● told him on't, but all's one, if he be married, let him play with his Queen tonight , and than tomorrow he'll call for me, th●res no fool tooth wilful still. What shall we do cousin?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: I'll go get the key of the wine-cellar, and thou and I'll keep a passage there tonight .

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: We have but a little wit between us already cousin, and so we should have none at all.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: When our wits be gone, we'll sleep ith' cellar, and lie without our wits for one night.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Content, and then ith' morning we'll but wet them with another cup more, and they'll shave like a razor all day after. Come close good coz, let nobody go with us, lest they be drunk before us, for fools are innocents, and must be accessary to no man's overthrow.

div.stage: Enter King, Queen Katherine, Cardinal, Semer, Dudly, gr●y, enter Cumpton, crying hobeyes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Welcome Queen Katherine, seat thee by our side,
Thy sight fair Queen, by us thus dignified,
Earls, flarro●, knights, and gentlemen,
Against ye all, we'll be chief challenger,
To fight at barriours, tilt, and tournament,
In honour of the fair Queen Katherine,

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: We thank your highness, and beseech your grace,
sp.l: Forbear such hazard of your royal person,
Without such honours is your handmaid pleased,
Obediently to yield all love and duty,
That may beseem your sacred majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: God a mercy, but where are our children?
Prince Edward, Mary, and Elizabeth,
The royal issue of three famous Queens,
How haps we have not seen them here today?

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: They all my liege attend your majesty,
And your fair Queen, so within the presence here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis well, Dudh● call Cranmer in,
He is chief tutor to our princely son,
For precepts that concern divinity.
And here he comes, Cranmer, you must ply the prince,
Let his waste hours be spent in getting learning:
And let those linguists for choice languages,
Be careful for him in their best endeavours,
Bid doctor tie, ply him to music hard,
He's apt to learn, therefore be diligent,
He may requite your love when we are gone.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Our care and duty shall be had my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We thank ye.
I tell thee Cranmer he is all our hopes,
That what our age shall leave unfinished,
In his fair reign shall be accomplished.
sp.p: Go and attend him, how now will Sommers, what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Vvil.
sp.p: I come to bid thee and thy new Queen god-morrow. Look to him Kate lest he cozen thee, provide civil oranges enough, or he'll have a lemon shortly.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Godamercy Will, thou'lt tell me then, wilt thou not?

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p:
I and watch him too, or let him never trust me: but dost hear Harry, because I'd have thee have the poors prayers, I have brought thee some petitions, the friars and priests pray too, but I think us as children say grace, more for fashion
than 〈…〉 heard, because they beg for godsake, therefore I prithee dispatch them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Read them Semer.

sp.speaker: Semer.
