sp.p: The humble petition of the lady Seaton, for her distressed son, that in his own defence, unhappily hath slain a man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The lady Seaton, God's holy mother,
Her son has had our pardon twice already,
For two stout subjects that his hand hath slain.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: And ●y had said so but thou harry, I'd have told him a lied, he ne'er killed but one, thou killed'st the tother: for and thou hadst hanged him for the first, the two last had been alive still.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The fool tells true, they wrong our majesty
That seek our pardon for such cruelty:
A way with it.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: Give me it again, it shall ne'er be seen more I assure ye● and I had known 'thad come for that purpose, it should ne'er have been brought for well I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Se.
sp.l: This other comes from two poor prisoners ith' counter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We know the inside then, come give them me,
Lord Cardinal, here's one is dedicated to you.
How! read it: who's there? Compto● inquire for Rookesby a
Groom of the wardrobe, and bring him hither.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Cardinal, what find ye written there?

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Mine own discredit, and the undoing of an honest citizen, by a false servant.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: 'Tis not your fool my lord I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: No will?

sp.speaker: Wub.
sp.p: I thought so, I knew 'twas one of your knaves, for your fools are harmless.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Well said Will thou lovest thy master's credit I know.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I Kate, as well as any courtier he keeps:
sp.p: I had rather he should have the poores prayers, than the Popes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Faith I am of thy mind will, I think so too.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take heed what ye say Kate, what a lutheran?

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: 'Tis heresy fair Queen, to think such thoughts.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: And much uncharity to wrong the poor?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, and when the Pope is at best, he is but saint Peter's deputy, but the poor, present Christ, and therefore should be something better regarded.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go too fool.

sp.speaker: W●l.
sp.l: Sirrah, you'll be whipped for this.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Would the King wood whip thee and all the Pope's whelps out of England once, for between ye, ye have racked and pulled it so, we shall be all poor shortly, you have had four hundred threescore pound within this three year for smokepence, you have smoked it i'faith: dost hear Harry, next time they gather them, let them take the chimneys, and leave the coin behind them, we have clay enough to make brick, though we want silver mines to make money.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well William your tongue is privileged.

sp.speaker: Vvol.
sp.l: But my good liege, I fear there's shroder heads
Although kept close, has set this fool a work,
Thus to extirp against his holiness.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.p: Do not you think so my lord, nor stomach nobody about it: ye know what the old proverb says, therefore be patient great quarrellers small credit wins:
When fools set stools, and wise men break their shins: therefore think not on it, for I'll sit down by thee Kate and say nothing, for here comes one to be examined.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O sir, you're welcome, is your name 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Rookes.
sp.l: Your poor servant is so called my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Our servant we geffe ye by the cloth ye wear, but for your poverty 'tis doubtful, your credit is so good. Let's see what's the man's name, ha! Hopkins, do you know the man?
〈…〉? No my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Had you never no dealings with such a man?

sp.speaker: Rookes.
sp.l: No, if it like your majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No, if it like our majesty, saucy varlet:
It likes not our majesty, thou shouldst say no:
It likes us not thou liest, for that we know.
You know him not, but he too well knows you,
And lies imprisoned slave, for what's thy due.

sp.speaker: Rookes.
sp.l: Sure some envious man hath misinformed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dar'st thou deny it still, outfacing knave,
Mother a God, I'll hang thee presently.
Sirrah ye lie: and though ye wear the King's cloth,
Yet we dare tell ye so before the King:
Slave thou dost know him.
He here complains he is undone by thee,
And the King's man hath caused his misery.
Yet you'll outface it still, deny, forswear, and lie fir, ha ▪

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Not a word more, if thou lovest thy life, unless thou● confess all, and speak fair.

sp.speaker: Rookes.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Out perjured knave, what dost thou serve the King.
And dar'st thou thus abuse our majesty:
And wrong my subjects by thy treachery?
Thinkst thou false thief, thou shalt be privileged
Because thou'rt my man, to hurt my people:
Villain, those that guard me, shall regard mine honour:
Put off that coat of proof, that strong security:
Under which ye march like a halbertere,
Passing through purgatory, and none dare strike:
A sergeants mace must not presume to touch
Your sacred shoulders with the Kings own wri● ▪
Gods dear lady, does the cloth ye wear,
Such privilege and strong prevention bear.
Ha, is't Rookesby?

sp.speaker: Rookes.
sp.l: My royal lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take that, and know your time to tell your
Message: sirrah, I am busy.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: So, there's one served: I think you would take two more with all your heart, so you were well rid on him.

sp.speaker: Rookes.
sp.l: Your pardon good my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ha, pardon these I tell thee did it touch thy life in ought , more than mine own displeasure, not the world should purchase it, vild ●aus●e: hadst thou neglected this thy duty to our persons danger: hadst thou thyself against me ought attempted, I might be sooner won to pardon thee, then for a subject's hateful injury.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Let me entreat your grace to pardon him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away Kate speak not for him,
Out of my lenity I let him live,
Discharge him from my cloth and countenance,
To the counter to redeem his creditor,
Where he shall satisfy the utmost mi●e
Of any debt, default or hindrance:
I'll keep no man to blur my credit so,
My cloth shall not pay what my servants owe.
Away with him.
Now my lord Cardinal, speaks not your paper so?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.p: Yes my good lord, your grace hath shown a pattern, to draw forth mine by, I assure your highness,
sp.l: The punishment inflicted on your man,
Is meant for mine servants that bears such minds,
Their masters thus but serves them in their kinds.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where's this fellow now that brings this news?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: He is gone with a flea in his ear: but has left his message behind with my lord Dudley, here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And what's the nowell.

sp.speaker: Dudlye.
sp.l: Duke Brandon my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O, he's returned from France:
And who comes with him?

sp.speaker: Dudlye.
sp.l: His royal wife, my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha● royal wife: who's that?

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Your highness' sister, the late Q. of France.

sp.speaker: K●●.
sp.l: Our sister Q. his 〈◊〉: who gave him her?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: 'Tis said they were married at donor, my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I were better he had ne'er seen the town.
Dares any subject mix his blood with ours, without our leave●

sp.speaker: Dudly.
sp.l: He comes himself my liege, to answer it.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Health to my sovereign.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: And our brother King, your message is before ye sir: off with his head.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I beseech your grace give me leave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay you have taken leave, away with him, bid the captain of our guard, convey him to the tower.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Hear me my lord.
Audacious Brandon, thinkst thou excuse shall serve.

sp.speaker: Lady Marry.
sp.l: Right gracious lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go too, your prayers will scarce save yourself,
Durst ye contract yourself without our knowledge?
Hence with that harebrain, Duke to the tower I say,
And bear our careless sister to the fleet:
I know sir, you broke a lance for her,
And bravely did unhorse the challengers:
Yet was there no such prize set on her head,
That you without our leave should marry her.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: O my lord, let me entreat for them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tut Kate, though thus I seem
A while to threaten them,
●meane not to disgrace my sister so:
A way with them. What say ye lords,
Is he not worthy death for his misdeed?

sp.speaker: Bon and Gar.
sp.l: Unless your grace shall please to pardon him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He deserves it then?

sp.speaker: Bon and Gar.
sp.l: He does my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You are knaves and fools, and ye flatter me:
God's holy mother, I'll not have him hurt, for all your heads:
Dear Brandon, I embrace thee in mine arms:
Kind sister, I love you both so well.
I cannot dart another angry from ●ne
To gain a kingdom: here take him mar●e,
I hold the happier in this English choice,
then to be Q. of France: Charles, love her well.
And tell on Brandon, what's the news in France.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: The league is broke betwixt the emperor
And the young King of France: forces are mustering
On either part my lord, for horse and foot.
Hot variance is expected speedily.
The emperor is marching now to Landersey,
There to invade the towns of Burgundy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: God and s. George, we'll meet his majesty,
And strike a league of Christian amity.
Lord Cardinal, you shall to France with speed,
And in our name salute the emperor,
We'll give direction for your embassage.
The next fair wind, shall make us France to greet,
Where Charles the emperor, and King shall meet.

div.stage: Enter Cranmar, doctor tie: and young Browne, meets them with the prince's cloak and hat.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: How now young brown, what have you there?

sp.speaker: Brown.
sp.l: The prince's cloak and hat, my lord.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Where is his grace?

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.l: At tennis, with the marquess Dorset.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: You and the marquess, draw the prince's mind
To follow pleasure, and neglect his book:
For which the King blames us. But credit me,
You shall be soundly paid immediately.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: I pray ye good my I. I'll go call the prince away.

sp.speaker: Crā.
sp.l: Nay, now ye shall not, who's within there ho? strai●e

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Go bear this youngster to the chapel,
And bid the m. of the children whip him well:
The prince will not learn sir, and you shall smart for it.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: O good my l. I'll make him ply his book tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: That shall not serve your turn, away I say.
sp.p: So sir, this policy was well devised: since he was whipped thus for the prince's faults,
sp.l: His grace hath got more knowledge in a month,
Than he attained in a year before,
For still the fearful boy to save his breech,
Doth hourly haunt him whereso ere he goes.

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: 'Tis true my lord, and now the prince perceives it,
As ●oath to see him punished for his faults,
Plays it of purpose to redeem the boy,
But pray my lord, let's stand aside awhile,
And note the greeting twixt the prince and him,

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: See where the boy comes and the King's fool with him; let's not be seen, but list their conference.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay boy, and ye cry you'll spoil your eye sight, come, come truss up your hose, you must hold fast your wind, both before and behind, and blow your nose.

sp.speaker: Browne,
sp.l: For what fool?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why for the mote in thine eye, is there not won in't, wherefore dost thou cry else?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: I prithee will go call the prince from the tennis-court.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Dost thou cry for that? nay then I smell a rat, the prince has played the truant today, and his tutors has drawn blood of thy buttocks fort: why boy 'tis honourable to be whipped for a prince.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: I would he would either leave the tennis-court and ply his book, or give me leave to be no courtier.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, for I'll be sworn thy breech lies ith' Hassard about it, but look little Ned, yonder he comes.

div.stage: Enter the prince, and the young marquess with their rackets, divers attending.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.l: Some rubbers for the prince.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Here my good lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: One take our rackets, and reach my cloak,
By my faith marquess, you are too hard for me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your grace will say so, though ye over match 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Why 〈…〉?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: 〈…〉 loiters, and will not ply your book, and your tutors has whipped me for it.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
Alas poor Ned, I am sorry for it, I'll take the more
pains, and entreat my tutors for thee: yet in troth, the lectors they read me last night out of Virgil and Ovid, I am perfect in: only I confess I am something behind in my Greek authors.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: And for that speech, they have declined it upon his breech.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And for my logic, thou shalt witness thyself I am perfect: for now will I prove ▪ that though thou wert whipped for me, yet this whipping was good for thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll hardly believe you my lord, though Ramus himself should prove it: well, probe.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Mark my problem.
Bona virga facit bonum pverum:
Bonum est, te esse bonum pverum:
Ergo bona vorga, res bona est: and that's this, Ned.
sp.p: A good rod makes a good boy: 'tis good that thou shouldst be a good boy: (Ergo) therefore a good rodis good.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Nay by’r lady, the better the rod is, it's the worse for him, that's certain: but dost hear me, boy; since he can prove a r●dde to be so good, let him take't himself next time.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: In truth, I pity thee ▪ and inwardly I feel the stripes thou barest, and for thy sake, Ned, I'll pile my book the faster; in the mean time, thou shalt not say, but the prince of Wales will honourably reward thy seru●●c●come, brown, kneel down.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What, wilt thou knight him, Ned?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I will; my father has knighted many a one, that never shed drop of blood for him; but he has often for me.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: O brave! he looks like the mirror of knighthood already.
Clear the presence, gentlemen, the King is coming.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: The King? gods me, reach 〈…〉 books call my tutors in: come ●rowne, I'll confirm thy knighthood afore the King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Here be your tutors, my lord, and yonder the King comes.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Health to your ▪ majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Godamercy Ned; ay, at your book so hard, 'tis well, 'tis well; now Bishop Cranmer, and good doctor tie, I was going to the gallery, and thought to have had your scholar with me, but seeing you're so busy, I'll not trouble him, come on Will, come, go you along with me, what make you among the scholars here?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I come to learn my quy que quod to keep me from the rod: mar here's one was whipped in pudding time for he has gotten a knighthood about it: look old Harry, does he not look more furious than he was wont.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Who W●, young Browne, gods marry mother, his father is a gallant knight, as any these sooth parts of England holds.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: He cannot compare with his son though, if he were right donsal delphebus, or the very knight of the sun himself, yet this knight shall unhorse him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When was he made a knight will.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Marry i●he last action, I can assure you, there was hot service, and some on 'em came so near him, they had like to smelled on't: but when all was done, the poor gentleman was pitifully wounded in the back parts, as may appear by the scar, if his knightship would but untruss there.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But who knighted him, William?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: That did Ned here: and he has earned it too, for I am sure, this two year he has been lashed, for his learning.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha, how, come hither Ned, is this true?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: It is, my lord, and I hope your highness will confirm my deed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Confirm it, god's holy mother, what shrewd boys are these? Cranmer and Tye, do ye observe the prince, now by my crown young Ned thou hast honoured me.
sp.l: I like thy kingly spirit that loves to see
Thy friends advanced to types of dignity.
Young knight come hither, what the prince hath done
We here confirm, be still sir Edward Browne:
But hear ye Ned, now you have made him knight,
You must give him some living, or else 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I by my troth, he is now but a knight under forma papris, for a knight without living is no better than an ordinary gallant.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well, what will ye give him Ned?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: When I have heard of something that may do him good, I will entreat your majesty for him, and ith' mean time from mine own allowance I'll maintain him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis well said: but for your sake son Edward, we'll provide for him; Cranmer, see presently a patent drawn, wherein were will confirm to him from our exchequer a thousand marks a year.

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.l: I thank your majesty.
And as I am true knight, I'll fight and die for ye.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Now if your tutors come to whip ye, you may choose whether you'll untruss byth' order of arms.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well Ned, ●ee ye ply your learning, and let's have no more knights made in this action, look to him brown, if he loiter, his tutors will have you up for't.

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.l: I hope my lord, they dare not whip me now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By’r lady sir, that's doubtful.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: If they do, he shall make thee a lord, and then they dare not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well Cranmer we'll leave ye, when your pupil has done his task ye set him now, let him come and visit us: on gentlemen into the gallery.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Heaven keep your majesty.
Gentlemen draw near.

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: Good morrow to your grace.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Good morrow tutors at noon, 'tis God even, is it not?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: We saw not your grace today.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: O ye quip me cunningly for my truantship ▪ that I was not at my book today, but I have thought of that ye read last night, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.p: We doubt it not fair prince: lords, gentlemen give leave.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: All void the room, there's but scholars and fools.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I hope your excellence can answer me in that axiom of philosophy, I propound to ye.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I promise ye tutor, 'tis a problem to me, for the difference of your author's opinions, makes me differ in mine own: some say, omne animalest, aut homo, aut bestia, that every living creature is, or man, or beast.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Then a woman's a beast, for she's no man.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Peace William you'll be expulsed else: and again some authors affirm, that every beast is fourfooted.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Then a fool's no beast, for he has but two.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Yet again will.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Mum Ned, no words, I'll be as still as a small bagpipe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Omne animal est, aut homo, aut bestia: and thus 'tis proved my lord, omne animal, est rationalis, vel irrationalis, homo est rationalis, bestia irrationalis,
sp.l: Ergo omne animal homo est, vel bestis:
Amongst all the creatures in this universe,
Or on the earth, or flying in the air,
Man only reason hath, others only sense,
So what is only sensual, in not man, but beast:
For man both sense and reason hath:
sp.p: So every creature, having one of these, is sure or man, or best: and though all beasts are not fourfooted.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: That's certain a louse has six.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: I beseech your grace.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: A way William.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Not a word more as I am William.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p:
For many beasts have wings serving in stead of feet, and some have horns, of which we thus esteem, animal cornutum non habet dentes supremas, no horned beast hath
teeth above the roof.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: That's a lie, a cuckold has.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Thrust the fool out of the presence there.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: Well, cedant arma toge, the scholars shall have the fool's place.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Well Cranmer, you have made me able to prove a man no beast, if he prove not himself so, we'll now leave this: and now resolve me for divinity, Cranmer I love ye, and I love your learning, speak and we'll hear ye:
sp.l: God give ye truth that you may give it me,
This land ye know stands wavering in her faith,
Betwixt the Papists and the Protestants,
You know we all must die, and this flesh
Part, with her part of immortality,
Tutor, I do believe both heaven and hell:
Do you know any third place for the soul's abode
Called purgatory, as some would have me think,
For from my sister Marry and her tutors,
I have oft received letters to that purpose:
I love ye Cranmer, and shall believe whate'er ye speak,
Therefore I charge ye tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: How thinks your grace, is there a place of purgatory or no?
P. truly I think none, yet must I urge to you what's laid
To me, this world you know hath been five thousand years
Still increasing, still decreasing, still replenished,
How long it will be, none knows but he that made it,
We all do call our selves gods children, yet sure some are not,
But think ye tutor that the compass of that heaven and hell,
Is able to contain those souls so numberless,
That ever breathed since the first breath was given,
Without a tertium, or a third place.
Who puts these doubts within your graceshead
Are like their own belief, slight, and unregarded,
And is as easily answered and confuted:
Quod est infinitum, non habet finem,
Calum est opus dei, opus dei est infinitum:
Ergo calum, est infinitum.
That which is infinite hath no end at all,
For that eternity, that everlasting essence,
that did concord heaven, earth, and hell to be
Is of himself all infinite, that heaven and hell are so,
His power, his works, and words do witness it,
For what is infinite, hath in it sell no-end,
Then must the heavens which is his glorious seat,
Be incomprehensible containing him,
Then what should need a third place to contain,
A world of infinites so vast and main.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I thank ye Cranmer, and do believe ye
What other proofs have been maintained to me
Or shall be, you shall know and aid me in them:
Enough for this time, who's there? Doctor tie
Our music's lecturer prey draw near: indeed I take much

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: In music may your grace ever delight, (Delight in ye though not in me, music is fit for Kings,
And not for those knows not the chime of strings.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Truly I love it yet there are a sort
Seeming more pure than wise, that will upbraid at it,
Calling it idle, vain, and frivolous.

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: Your grace hath said, indeed they do upbraid
That term it so, and those that do are such
As in themselves no happy concord's hold,
All music jars with them, but sounds of good.
But would your grace a while be patient,
In musics praise, thus will I better it.
Music is heavenly, for in heaven is music,
For there the seraphins do sing continually,
And when the best was born, that ever was man,
A choir of angels sang for joy of it,
What of celestial was revealed to man,
Was much of music, 'tis said the beasts did worship
And sang before the deity supernal,
The kingly prophet sang before the ark,
And with his music charmed the heart of Saul,
And if the poet sail us not my lord,
The dulcet tongue of music made the stones
To move, irrational beast, and birds to dance
And last, the trumpets music shall awake the dead,
and cloth their naked bones in coats of flesh,
T'appear in that high house of parliament,
When those that gnash their teeth at music sound,
Shall make that place where music ne'er was found.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Thou givest it perfect life, skilful doctor
I thank thee for the honoured praise thou givest it,
I pray thee let's hear it too.

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: 'Tis ready for your grace, give breath to your loud tuned instruments.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: 'Tis well, methinks in this sound I prove a complete age,
As music, so is man governed by stops,
Awed by dividing notes, sometimes aloft,
Sometime below, and when he hath attained,
His high and lofty pitch, breathed his sharpest and most
Shrillest air, yet at length 'tis gone,
And falls down flat to his conclusion,
Another sweetness, and harmonious sound,
A milder strain, another kind agreement,
Yet amongst these many strings, be one untuned
Or jarreth low, or higher than his course
Not keeping steady mean amongst the rest,
Corrupts them all, so doth bad men the best.

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: Enough; let voices now delight his princely care.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Doctor, I thank you and commend your cunning.
I est have heard my father merrily speak,
In your high praise, and thus his highness say,
England, one God, one truth, one doctor hath
For music's art, and that is doctor tie,
Admired for skill in musics harmony.

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: Your grace doth honour me with kind acceptance,
Yet one thing more, I do beseech your excellence
To deign, to patronize this homely work,
Which I unto your grace have dedicated.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What is the title?

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: The acts of the holy apostles turned into verse,
Which I have set in several 〈◊〉 to sing,
Worthy acts, and worthily in you remembered.
I'll peruse them, and satisfy your pains,
And have them sung within my father's chapel.
I thank ye both. Now I'll crave leave a while
To be a little id●e: pray let our linguists,
French and Italians, tomorrow morn be ready,
I must confer with them, or I shall lose
My little practice. so god-den good tutors.

sp.speaker: Cra●.
sp.l: Health to your highness, God increase your days:
The hope of England, and of learning's praise.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: What have ye here my lord of Winchester?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Heretical and damned heresies,
Precepts that crammers wisdom taught the prince,
The Pope and we are held as heretics,
What thinkst thou Bonner of this wouering age?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: As seamen do of storms, yet hope for fair weather,
By’r lady gardener we must look about,
The Protestants begin to gather head,
Luther hath sown well, and England's ground
Is fat and fertile to increase his seed,
Here's lofty plants, what, Bishops and prelates,
I nobility temporal, but we shall temper all
At the return of our high Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Bonner 'tis true, but in mean time we must
Prevent this rancour that now swells so big,
That it must out or break, they have a dangerous head,
And much I fear.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: What not the King I hope?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: 'Tis doubtful he will bend, but sure
Queen Katherine's a strong Lutheran hard ye not
How in presence of the King and Cardinal,
She did exsterp against his holiness.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: But had our English Cardinal once attained,
The high possession of saint Peter's chair,
Heed bar some tongues than now have scope too much,
'Tis he must do't gardener, '〈◊〉 perilous thing,
Queen Katherin can do much with England's King.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I Bonner, that's the sum of all,
there must be no Queen, or the abbeys fall,

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: See where she comes with the King's sister,
And from the prince's lodging, let's salute her.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Good morrow to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Good morrow to my reverent lords of London and of Winchester, saw ye the King today?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: His highness was not yet abroad this morning.
But here we will attend his excellence.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Come sister we'll go see his majesty.

sp.speaker: La. mace_bearer
sp.l: We will attend ye madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Gentlemen set forward, good morrow lords.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Ill morrow must it be to you or us,
Conspirators 'gainst men religious,
Bonner, these Lutherans do conspire I see,
And scoff the Pope and his supremacy.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Let's strike in time then, and incense the King,
And suddenly their stares to ruin bring:
The trumpets sounds, it seems the Queen is coming.
We'll watch and take advantage cunningly.

div.stage: Enter the King, Queen, lady Marry, Brandon, Semer ▪ Grey, and Dudley.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where's Brandon?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: My liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come hither Kate.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Did your grace call?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: I'll speak we anon, I'll speak we anon: come Kate let's walk a little, who's there? my lords of London and of Winchester, welcome, welcome: by this your master the Cardinal I trow, has parted with the emperor, and set a league between the French and him, mother of God,
sp.l: I would ourself in person had been there,
But Wolsey's diligence we need not fear,
Ha think ye he will not.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: No doubt he will my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I Gardner 'twill be his best policy,
Their friendship must advance his dignity.
If ere he get the papal governance.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: And that will never be I hope.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: 'Twere pity it should.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: He's proud enough already.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Haw, what's that ye talk there.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: They say my lord he's gone with such a train, as if he should be elected presently.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Fore-god 'tis a gallant priest, come hither Charles prithee let me lean a thy shoulder, by saint George, Kate● grow stiff methinks .

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Will't please your highness sit and rest yourself?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No, no Kate, I'll walk still, Brandon shall stay mine arm, I me fat and pursy, and 'twill get me a stomach: sawest the prince today Kate?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I my good lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: God bless him, and make him fortunate, I tell ye lords, the hope that England hath, is now in him, fore-god I think old Harry must leave ye shortly; well, gods will be done, here'll be old shuffling then, ha will there not; well, you say nothing, pray God there be not, I like not this difference in religion I, god's dear lady, and I live but seven year longer, we'll take order thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: We hear that Luther out of Germany
Hath with a book unto your majesty,
Wherein he much repents his former deeds,
Craving your highness' pardon, and withal,
Submits himself unto your grace's pleasure.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Bonner 'tis true, and we have answered it,
Blaming at first his haughty insolence,
And now his lightness and inconstancy,
That writ he knew not what so childishly.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Much bloodshed there is now in Germany,
About this difference in religion,
With Lutherans, Arians, and Anabaptists
As half the province of Helvetia,
Is with their tumults almost quite destroyed.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Methinks 'twere well my royal sovereign,
Your grace, the emperor, and the Christian Kings,
would call a counsel and peruse the books,
That Luther writ against the Catholics,
And superstitions of the church of Rome:
And if they teach a truer way to heaven,
Agreeing with the hebrew testament,
Why should they not be red and followed?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Thou sayest well Kate, so they agree with the scriptures, I think 'tis lawful to peruse and read them, speak Bishops?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Most unlawful my dear sovereign,
Unless permitted by his holiness.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: How prove ye that my lord?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Well said Kate, to them again good wench, lords give us leave awhile, avoid the presence there, we'll hear the Bishops and my Queen dispute.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I am a weak scholar my lord,
But on condition that your highness, not these reverent lords,
Will take no exceptions at my woman's wit,
I am content to hold them argument:
And first with reverence to his majesty.
Pray tell me, why would ye make the King believe.
His highness and the people under him,
Are tied so strictly to obey the Pope?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Because fair Queen he is god's deputy.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: So are all Kings; and God himself commands
The King to rule, and people to obey.
And both to love and honour him:
But you that are sworn servants unto Rome,
How are ye faithful subjects to the King,
When first ye screw the Pope then after him?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Madam these are that sects of Lutherans,
That makes your highness so mistake the scriptures,
Your slender arguments thus answered
Before the King, God 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: 'Tis true, but pray ye answer this:
Suppose, the King by proclamation,
Commanded you and 〈…〉,
To spurn against the Pope's authority:
ye know the scripture binds ye to obey him,
But this I think, if that his grace did so,
Your slight obedience all the world should know.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Godsmother Kate, thou'st touched them there,
What say ye to that Bonner?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Were it to any but her majesty,
These questions were confuted easily.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Pray tell the King then, what scripture have ye,
To teach religion in an unknown language?
Instruct the ignorant to kneel to saints,
By barefoot pilgrimage to visit shrines,
For money to release from purgatory,
The vildest villain, thief, or murderer,
All this the people must believe you can,
Such is the dregs of Rome's religion.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Ay, those are the speeches of those heretics,
Cranmer, Ridley, and blunt Lattimer,
That daily rail against his holiness,
Filling the land with hateful heresies.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Nay be not angry, nor mistake them lords,
What they have said or done, was mildly followed,
As by their articles are evident.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where are those articles Kate?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I'll go and fetch them to your majesty,
And pray your highness view them graciously.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Go fetch them Kate: a sirta, we have women doctors,
Now I see, mother a God, here's a fine world the whilst,
That twixt so many men's opinions,
The holy scriptures must be banded thus.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: God grant it breed no farther detriment,
Unto your crown and sacred dignity:
They that would alter thus religion,
I fear they scarcely love your royal person.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ha ▪ take heed what you say gardener.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: My love and duty to your majesty,
Bids me be bold to speak my conscience,
Unless your safety and your life they hate,
Why should they daily thus disturb the state.
To smooth the face of false rebellion,
Proud traitors will pretend religion.
For under colour of reformation
The upstart followers of Wickliff's doctrine,
In the fifth Henry's days arise in arms:
And had nor diligent care prevented them,
Their powers had suddenly surprised the King.
And good my liege who knows their proud intent,
That thus rebel against your government.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Shrewd proofs by’r lady and by saint Peter,
I swear we will not trust their gentleness,
Speak Gardner and resolve us speedily,
Who's the ringleader of this lusty crew?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Unless your highness please to pardon us,
We dare not speak nor urge your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We pardon what ye speak, resolve us speedily.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Then if your royal person will be safe,
Your life preserved and this fair realm in peace.
And all these troubles smoothly pacified,
The Queen dear lord must be removed from you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Haw, the Queen, bold sir advise ye well,
Take heed ye do not wrong her loyalty.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: See here my liege are proofs too manifest,
Her highness with a sect of Lutherans:
Have private meetings, secret conventicles,
To wrest the grounds of all religion:
Seeking by tumults to subvert the state,
The which without your majesty's consent,
Is treason capital against the crown.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: And seeing without the knowledge of your grace,
They dare attempt these dangerous stratagems,
'Tis to be feared, which heaven we pray prevent,
They do conspire against your sacred life.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Why else, should all these private meetings be without the knowledge of your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Mother a god these proofs are probable,
sp.p: And strong presumptions do 〈◊〉 your words, within there, ho?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sir William Compton see the doors made fast ▪
Double our guard let none come near our person ▪
Summon the counsel to confer with us,
Bid them attend us in the printy chamber,

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Here is a letter for your majesty,
From Martin Luther out of Germany.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Da●bd schismatic still will he trouble us with books and letters, leave it and be gone ▪
sp.l: The villain thinks to smooth his treachery,
By fawning speeches to our majesty,
But by my George lord Bishops if I live,
I'll root his favourites from England's bounds
What writes his worship?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Now Bonner stir, the game is set a foot,
The King is now incensed, let's follow close
To have Queen Katherne shorter by a head,
These heresies will cease when she is dead.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Holy saint Peter what a knave is this,
Ere while he writ submissively to us;
And now again repents his humbleness,
Bishops it seems being touched with our reply
He wrights thus boldly to our majesty,
Gardner look here he was deceived he says
When he thought to find John Baptist in the
Courts of princes, or resident with those that are
Clothed in purple, mother a god, is't not a dangerous knave.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: False Luther knaves he has great friends in England:
Else durst he not thus move your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We'll cut his friends off, ere they grow too strong
And sweep these vipers from our state ere long,
No marvel though Queen Katherne plead for him,
That is I see the greatest Lutheran,
How is your counsels we proceed in these?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: 'Twere best your grace did send her to the tower.
Before they further do consit with her.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let it be so, go get a warrant drawn,
And with a strong guard bear her to the tower.
Our hand shall sign your large commission,
Let Cranmer from the prince be straight removed,
And come not near the court on pain of death,
Mother a God, shall I be baffled thus,
By traitors, rebels and false heretics:
Get articles for her arraignment ready,
If she of treason be convict, I swear,
Her head goes off, were she my kingdom's air.

div.stage: Enter the prince, Cranm: Tye, and the young lords.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Cranmer.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Where is Francisco our Italian tutor?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: He does attend your grace without my lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Tell him anon we will confer with him,
We'll ply our learning brown lest you be beaten,
We will not have your knighthood so disgraced.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: I thank ye good my lord,
And your grace would but a little ply your learning,
I warrant ye I'll keep my knighthood from breeching.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Faith Ned I will: how now what letter's that?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: From your grace's sister the lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Come give it me, we guess at the contents.
Cranmer, my sister oft hath writ to me,
That you and Bishop Bonner might confer,
About these points of new religion,
Tell me tutor will ye dispute with him.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Withal my heart my lord, and wish the King,
Would deign to hear our disputation.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: What hast thou there?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: A letter from your royal sister, young Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Another letter ere we open this,
Well we will view them both immediately,
I pray ye attend us in the next chamber,
And tutors if I call ye not before,
Give me some notice, if the King my father
Be walked abroad, I must go visit him.

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: We will fair prince.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: What says my sister Mary? she is eldest,
and by due course must first be answered,
sp.stage: The blessed 〈◊〉 of thy redeemer, with all the angels and 〈…〉 to preserve thee of idolatry, to 〈…〉 for help.
sp.l: Alas good sister still in this opinion,
These are thy blinded tutors, Bonner, Gardner,
That wrong thy thoughts with foolish heresies,
He read no farther: to him will Edward pray
For 〈◊〉, that can himself preserve me,
Without the help of saint or ceremony.
What writes 〈◊〉 sweet sister thou hast my heart.
And of prince Edward's love hast greatest part.
〈…〉 with a sister's love,
Be 〈◊〉 in thy such, and let thy prayers
〈…〉 to God only for 'tis he alone
〈…〉 thee, and confound thine enemies,
〈…〉 assurance of thy hopes in heaven,
〈…〉 thee in all temptations,
〈…〉 grace to shun idolatry,
〈…〉 life to inherit thy election,
To God I commend thee, who still I pray preserve thee.
Loving thou art, and of me best beloved.
Thy lines shall be my contemplations cures,
And in thy virtues will I meditate,
To Christ I'll only pray for me and thee:
This I embrace, away idolatry,
How now Cranmer, where's the King?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Conferring with his counsel gracious prince,
There is some earnest business troubles him:
The guards are doubled, and commandment given,
That none be suffered to come near the presence,
God keep his majesty from traitors hands.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Amen good Cranmer, what should disturb him thus?
Is Cardinal Wolsey yet returned from France?

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: I my good lord, and this day comes to court.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Perhaps this hasty business of the King,
Is touching Wolsey and his embassage.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Pray God it be no worse my lord.

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: Here comes sir William Compton from his highness.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Health to your excellency.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: What news sir William?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: The King expects your grace's company,
And wills vout highness come and speak with him,
And doctor Cranmer, from his majesty,
I charge ye speedily to leave the court,
And come not near the prince on pain of death,
Without direction from the King and peers.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Sir I obey ye God so deal with me,
As I have wished unto his majesty.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Cranmer banished the court for what I pray?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: I know not gracious lord, pray pardon me,
'Tis the King's pleasure; and trust me I am sorry
It was my hap to bring this heavy message.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Nay good sir William, your message moves not me,
My service to his royal majesty
Was always true and just, so help me heaven:
Only I pray your grace to move the King,
That I may come to trial speedily,
And if in ought I have deserved death,
Let me not draw another minute's breath.

sp.speaker: Compt.
sp.l: Will ye go my lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Not yet, we are not your prisoner, are we sir?

sp.speaker: Compt.
sp.l: No my dear lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Then go before, and we will follow ye,
Your worship will forget yourself I see,
My tutor thrust from court so suddenly, this is strange.

sp.speaker: Tye.
sp.l: The Queen my lord is come to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Avoid the presence then, and conduct her in,
I'll speak with her, and after see the King,

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Leave us alone I pray ye.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Your grace is welcome, how fares your majesty.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Never so ill dear prince, for now I fear,
Even as a wretched caitiff killed with care,
I am accused of treason, and the King
is now in counsel to dispose of me,
I know his frown is death, and I shall die.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Who are your accusers.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: How know ye then his grace is so incensed.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: One of my gentlemen passing by the presence,
Took up this bill of accusations,
Wherein twelve articles are drawn against me,
It seems my false accusers lost it there,
Here they accuse me of conspiracy,
That I with Cranmer, Lutimer and Ridley,
Do seek to raise rebellion in the state,
Alter religion, and bring Luther in,
And to new government enforce the King,

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Then that's the cause that Cranmer was removed,
But did your highness e'er confer with them?
As they have here accused ye to the King.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Never nor ever had I one such thought,
As I have hope in him my soul hath bought.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Then fear not gracious madam, I'll to the King,
And doubt not but I'll make your peace with him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O plead for me, tell him my soul is clear,
Never did thought of treason harbour here,
As I intended to his sacred life,
So be it to my soul or joy or grief.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Stay here till I return, I'll move his majesty,
That you may answer your accusers presently.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O I shall never come to speak with him,
The lion in his rage is not too stern,
As royal Herry in his wrathful spleen,
And they that have accused me to his grace,
Will work such means I near shall see his face,
Wretched Queen Katherin, would thou hadst been
Kate Parr still, and not great England's Queen,

sp.speaker: Compt.
sp.l: Health to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Wish me good Compton woe and misery,
This giddy flattering world I hate and scoff,
Ere long I know Queen katherins head must off.
Came ye from the King?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: I did fair Queen, and much sad tidings bring,
His grace in secret hath revealed to me
What is intended to your majesty,
Which I in love and duty to your highness,
Am come to tell ye and to counsel ye
The best I can in this ex●remine.
Then on my knees I dare entreat your grace,
Not to reveal what I shall say to you,
For then I am assured that death's my due.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I will not on my faith, good Compton speak,
That with thy sad reports my heart may break.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Thus then at your fair feet my life I lay,
In hope to drive your highness cares away:
You are accused of high conspiracy
And treason 'gainst his royal maiesty.
So much they have incensed his excellency,
That he hath granted fi●●e commission
To attach your person and convey ye hence,
Close prisoner to the tower, articles are drawn,
And time appointed for arraignment there.
Good madam be advised by this I know,
The officers are sent to arrest your person:
Prevent their malice, haste ye to the King.
I'll use such means that you shall speak with him,
There plead your innocency, I know his grace
Will hear ye mildly therefore delay not,
If you be taken ere you see the King,
I fear ye never more shall speak to him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O Compton twixt thy love and my sage fear,
I feel ten thousand sad vexations here,
Lead on I pray, I'll be advised by thee,
The King is angry and the Queen must die.

div.stage: Enter Boner and Gardner with the commission.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Come Boner now strike sure the irons hot.
Urge all thou canst, let nothing be forgotten.
We have the King's hand here to warrant us,
'Twas well the Cardinal came and so luckily.
Who urged, the state would quite be ruined,
If that religion thus were altered.
Which made his highness with a fiery spleen,
Direct out warrants to attach the Queen.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: 'Twas excellent, that cedar once o'erthrown,
To crop the lower shrubs let us alone.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Those articles of accusations,
We framed against her being lost by you
Had like to overthrow our policy,
Had we not stoutly urged his majesty.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Well well, what's now to be done.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: A guard must be provided speedily,
To bear her prisoner unto London tower,
And watch convenient place to arrest her person.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Tush any place shall serve for who dare contradict
His highness' hand, even from his side we'll hale her,
And bear her quickly, to her longest home,
Lest we and ours by her to ruin come.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: About it then, let them untimely die, that scorn the Pope and Rome's supremacy.

div.stage: Enter the King and prince, the guard before them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Guard, watch the doors and let none come near us,
But such as are attendant on our person
Mother a God 'tis time to stir, I see,
When traitors creeps so near our majesty:
Must English 〈◊〉 walk with armed guards,
Now in his old age, must I fear my life,
By hateful treason of my Queen and wife.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I do beseech your royal majesty,
To hear her speak ere ye condemn her thus.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Go too Ned, I charge ye speak not for her, she's a dangerous traitor how now, who knocks so loud there.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: 'Tis Cardinal Wolsey my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And it be the devil tell him he comes not here.
Bid him attend us tell our better leisure:
Come hither Ned let me confer with you.
Didst ever hear the disputation
Twixt Cranmer and the Queen about religion.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Never my lord, I think they never yet,
At any time had speech concerning it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O thou art deceived Ned, it is too certain,
Heyday more knocking, knock irons an his heels,
And bear him hence whate'er he be disturb us, who is't?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: S. William Compton my liege.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Is't he, well let him in, god's holy mother, here's a stir indeed, Compton ye knock too loud for entrance here.
You care not though the King be ne'er so near, say ye sir haw.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: I do beseech you pardon for my boldness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well what's your business.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: The Queen my lord entreats to speak with you,

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Body a me, is she not rested yet.
Why do they not convey her to the tower,
We gave commission to attach her presently.
Where is she?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: At the door my sovereign.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: So near our presence, keep her out I charge ye.
Bend all your holbeards points against the door,
If she presume to enter strike her through,
Dare she presume again to look on us.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Upon my knees, I do beseech your highness
To hear her speak.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Up Ned, stand up I will not look on her,
Mother a god, stand close and guard it sure,
If she come in, I'll hang ye all I swear.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I do beseech your grace.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sir boy no more I'll here no more of her,
Proud slut, bold traitress, and forgetful beast,
Yet dare she further move our patience.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I'll pawn my princely word, right royal father,
She shall not speak a word to anger ye.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Will you pawn your word for her mother a god
The prince of Wales his word is warrant for a King,
And we will take it Ned, go call her in.
Sir William let the guard attend without,
Reach me a chair, all but the prince depart.
How now, what do you weep and kneel,
Does your black soul the guilt of conscience feel,
Out, out, your a traitor.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: A traitor, oh you all seeing powers,
Here witness to my lord my loyalty
A traitor. O then you are too merciful,
If I have treason in me, why rip ye not
My ugly heart out with your weapon's point,
Oh my good lord, if it have traitors blood,
It will be black, deformed, and tenebrous,
If not, from it will spring a scarlet fountain,
And spit defiance in their perjured throats
That have accused me to your majesty,
Making my state thus full of misery.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Canst thou deny it.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Else should I wrongfully accuse myself,
Of my dear lord I do beseech your highness
To satisfy your wronged Queen in this,
Upon what ground grows this suspicion,
Or who thus wrongfully accuseth me.
Of cursed treason 'gainst your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Some probable effects myself can witness,
Others our faithful subjects, can testify:
Have you not oft maintained arguments,
Even to our face against religion:
Which joined with other complots show itself,
As it is gathered by our loyal subjects,
For treason capital against our person,
God's holy mother you'll remove us quickly,
And turn me out, old Harry must away,
Now in mine age, lame and half bedrid,
Or else you'll keep me fast enough in prison,
Haw, mistress, these are no hateful treasons these.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Heaven on my forehead write my worst intent,
And let your hate against my life be bent,
If ever thought of ill against your majesty,
Was harboured here refuse me gracious God,
To your face, my ledge, if to your face I speak it.
It manifests no complot, nor no treason,
Nor are they loyal that so injure 〈◊〉;
What I did speak, was as my woman's wit,
To hold out argument could compass it,
My puny scholarship is held too weak
To maintain proofs about religion,
Alas I did it but to waste the time,
Knowing as then your grace was weak and sickly,
So to expel part of your pain and grief:
And for my good intent they seek my life,
Oh God, how am I wronged.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ha, saist thou so, was it no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: What should I say, that you might credit me,
If I am false, heaven strike me suddenly.

sp.speaker: Ki●g.
sp.p: Body a me, what everlasting knaves are these that wrong thee thus, alas poor Kate, come stand up stand up, wipe thine eyes, wipe thine eyes, fore-god 'twas told me that thou wert a traitor: I could hardly think it, but that it was applied so hard to me, godsmother Kate I fear my life I tell ye, King Harry would be loath to die by treason now, that has bid so many brunts unblemished, yet I confess that now I grow siff, my legs fail me first but they stand furthest from my heart, and that's still sound, I thank my God, give me thy hand, come kiss me Kate, so now ●●e friends again, hurson knaves, crafty varlets, make thee a traitor to old Harry's life, well, well, I'll meet with some on them, sfoot come sit on my knee Kate. Mother a god he that says thou'rt false to me by England's crown I'll hang him presently.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: When I have thought of ill against your state,
Let me be made the vildest reprobate.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: That's my good Kat●, but byth' marry god, Queen katherne you must thank prince Edward here.
sp.l: For but for him thou'dst gone tooth tower I swear,

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I shall be ever thankful to his highness.
And pray for him and for your majesty,

sp.p: Come Kate we'll walk a while ith' garden here, who keeps the dote there?

sp.speaker: Compt:
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sir William Compton, here take my ring,
Bid doctor Cranmer haste to cou●t again,
Give him that token of King Henry's love,
Discharge our guards, we fear no traitors hand.
Our state, beloved of all doth firmly stand:
Go Compton.

sp.speaker: Comp:
sp.l: I go my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Bid Wolsey haste him to our royal presence,
Great Charles the mighty Roman emperor,
Our nephew, and the hope of Christendom
Is landed in our fair dominion,
To see his uncle and the English court;
We'll entertain him with imperial port:
Come hither Ned.

div.stage: Enter Bonner and Gardner with the guard.

sp.speaker: G●●:
sp.l: Fellows, stay there, and when I call, come forward,
The service you pursue, is for the Kings
Therefore I charge you to perform it boldly,
We have his hand and seal to warrant it.

sp.speaker: Guard:
sp.l: We'll fellow you with resolution sir,
The church is on our side, what should we fear?

sp.speaker: Gard:
sp.l: See yonder, she's talking with his majesty,
Think you we may attempt to take her here?

sp.speaker: Bon:
sp.l: Why should we not, have we not firm commission
To attach her anywhere ? be bold, and fear not:
Fellows come forward.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How now, what's here to do?

sp.speaker: Queen:
sp.p: The Bishops it seems my lord would speak with you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: With bills and halberds, well, tarry there Kate,
I'll go myself; now wherefore come you?

sp.speaker: Gard:
sp.l: As loyal subjects to your state and person,
We come to apprehend that traitorous woman.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Y' are a couple of 〈…〉
God's holy mother, she is more true and just,
than any prelate that suborns the pops:
Thus to usurp upon our government?
sp.p: Call you her traitor? you're lying beasts and false conspirators.

sp.speaker: Bon:
sp.l: Your majesty hath seen what proofs we had.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Here you Bonner, you are a whoreson coxcomb, what proofs had ye, but treasons of your own inventions?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: O my dear lord, respect the reverend Bishops.
sp.l: Bonner and Gardner loves your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Alas poor Kate, thou think'st full little what they come for;
sp.l: Thou hast small reason to commend their loves,
That falsely have accused thy harmless life.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O God, are these mine enemies?

sp.speaker: Gard:
sp.l: We have your highness' hand to warrant it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let's see it then.

sp.speaker: Gard:
sp.l: 'Tis here my liege.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: So, now ye have both my hand to contradict what one hand did: and now our word again shall serve as warrant to bear you both as prisoners to the fleet, where you shall answer this conspiracy.
sp.l: You fellows that came to attack the Queens,
Lay hands on them, and bear them to the fleet.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O I beseech your highness on my knees,
Re●●t the doo●e of their imprisonment.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Stand up good Kate, thou wrongest thy majesty,
To plead for them that thus have injured thee

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I have forgotten it, and do still entreat
Then humble pardons at your gracious ●●et.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Mother of God, what a foolish woman's this,
Well, for her sake we revoke our doom,
But come not near us as you love your lives:
Away and leave us, you are knaves and miscreants,
Whoreson caitiffs, come to attach my Queen!

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Vex not my lord it will distemper you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Mother a God, I'll temper some on them for't
How now Branden?

sp.speaker: Bran:
sp.l: The emperor my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Get a train ready there, Charles Branden, come
We'll meet the monarch of imperial Rome:
Go Ned, prepare yourself to meet the emperor,
We'll send you further notice of our pleasure.
Attend the prince there: welcome lord Cardinal,
Hath not our tedious journey into France,
Disturbed your grace's health and reverent person?

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.l: No, no, never fear hun harry, he has got
More by the journey, he'll be Pope shortly.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: What, William, how chance I have not seen you today? I thought you would not have been the hindmost man to salute me.

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.p: No more I am not harry, for yonder is patch behind me, I could never get him before me, since thou conjur'st him i'th great chamber, all the horse i'th town cannot haul him into thy presence I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Will he not come in?

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.l: Not for the world, he stands watching at the door.
He'll not stir while the Cardinal come;
Then the fool will follow him everywhere .

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: I thank you William, I am beholding to you still.

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.p: Na my lord, I am more beholding unto you, I thank your fool for it, we have ransacked your winesellers since you went into France: do you blush my lord? nam, that's nothing, you have wine there, is able to set a colour in any man's face I warrant it.

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: Why William, is the Cardinal's wine so good?

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.p: Better then thine I'll be sworn, I'll take but two handfuls of his wine, and it shall fill four hogsheads of thine (Look here else)

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: Mordieu.

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.p:
More devil; is't not? for without commuting, you could never do it: but I pray you my lord call upon mor dieu no longer, but speak plain English, you have
deceived the King in French and Latin long enough a conscience.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is his wine turned into gold, Will?

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: The fool mistakes, my gracious sovereign.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Ay, i my lord, never set your wit to the fools, will Summers will be secret now, and say nothing, if I would be a blab of my tongue, I could tell the King how many barrels full of gold and silver there was six times filled with plate and jewels, twenty great trunks with crosses, crosiers, copes, mitres, maces, golden crucifixes, besides the four hundreth and twelve thousand pound that poor chimneys paid for Peter pence. But this is nothing, for when you are Pope, you may pardon yourself for more knavery ●●en this comes to.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Go too fool, you wrong the Cardinal,
But grieve not woolsey, William will be bold:
I pray you set on to meet the emperor,
The mayor and citizens are gone before,
The prince of Wales shall follow presently,
And with our George and collar of estate,
Present him with the order of the garter:
Great Maximilian his progenitor,
Upon his breast did wear the English cross,
And underneath our standard marched in arms,
Receiving pay for all his warlike hos●e;
And Charles with knighthood shall be honoured:
Begin lord Cardinal, greet his majesty,
And we ourself will follow presently.

sp.speaker: W●l:
sp.l: I go my sovereign.

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.l: Fair weather after ye:
sp.p: Well, and ere he come to be Pope, I shall be plunged for this.
Queen William, you have angered the Cardinal I can tell you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Tis no matter Kate, I'll anger him worse are long,
Though for a while I smooth it to his face:
I did suspect what here the fool hath found,
He keeps forsooth; a high court legantine,
taxing our subjects, gathering sums of gold,
Which he belike hath hid to make him Pope;
A god's name let him, that shall be our own.
But to our business, come Queen Katherin,
You shall with us to meet the emperor,
Let all your ladies be in readiness:
Go, let our guard attend the prince of Wales,
Upon ourself, the lords and pensioners
Shall give attendance in their best array,
Let all estates be ready ▪ come fair Kate,
The emperor shall see our English state.

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: Your majesty is welcome into England,
The King our master, will rejoice to see
Great Charles the royal emperor's majesty.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: We thank your pains my good l. Cardinal,
And much our longing eyes desires to see
Our kingly uncle and his princely son,
And therefore, when you please I pray set on.

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: On gentlemen, and meet the prince of Wales.
That comes forerunner to his royal father,
To entertain the Christian emperor:
Meanwhile , your majesty may here behold
This warlike kingdom fair metropolis,
The city London, and the river Thames,
And note the situation of the place.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: We do my lord, and count it admirable:
But see lord admiral, the prince is coming.

div.stage: Enter the prince with a herald before him, bearing the collar and garter, the guard and lords attending.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Well met young cousin.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I kiss your highness' hand.
And bid you welcome to my father's lands
I shall not need infer comparisons,
Welcome beyond compare, for so your excellency
Hath honoured England, in containing you,
As with all princely pomp and state we can,
We'll entertain great Charles the Austrian:
And first, in sign of honour to your grace,
I here present this collar of estate,
This golden garter of the knighthood's order,
An honour to renown the emperor:
Thus as my father hath commanded me,
I entertain your royal maiesty.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: True honoured offspring of a famous King
Thou dost amaze me, and dost make me wish
I were a second son to England lord,
In interchange of my imperial seats
To live with thee 〈◊〉 hope of majesty,
So well our welcome we accept of thee,
And with such princely spirit pronounce the word,
Thy father's state, can no more state afford.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Yes my good lord, in him there's majesty,
In me there's love with tender infancy.

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.p: The trumpets sound my lord, the King is coming.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Go all of you attend his royal person,
Whilst we observe the emperor's majesty.

div.stage: Enter the heralds first, then the trumpets next the guard, then mace-bearer and swords, then the Cardinal, then Branden, then the ●ing, after him the Queen, lady Marry, and ladies attending.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Hold, stand I say.

sp.speaker: Bran:
sp.l: Stand gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: Cease those trumpets there.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is the emperor yet come in sight of us?

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: His majesty is hard at hand my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Then 〈◊〉, sheathe sword and bear our maces down,
sp.l: In honour of my lord, the emperor:
Forward again.

sp.speaker: Bran:
sp.p: On gentlemen afore, sound trumpets and set forward.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Behold my father, gracious emperor.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: We'll meet him cousin:
sp.p: Uncle of England, King of France and Ireland, defender of the ancient Christian faith;
sp.l: With greater joy I do embrace thy breast,
Then when the seven electors crowned me,
Great emperor of the Christian monarchy.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Great charles, the first emperor of Almaigne, King of the Romans, semper Augustus, warlike King of Spain and Sicily, both Naples, Navarre and Arragon, King of Crete and great lerusalem, archduke of Austria, Duke of Milan, Brabant, Burgundy, Tyrrell and Flanders, with this great title I embrace thy breast,
sp.l: And how thy sight doth please, suppose the rest,
Sound trumpets, while my fair Queen Katerne
Gives entertainment to the emperor.
Welcome again to England princely cousin,
We dwell here, but in an outward continent,
Where winters icicles hangs on our beards,
Bordering upon the frozen Orcades,
Our mother-point, compassed with the Arctic sea,
Where raging Boreas sties from winter's mouth,
Yet are our bloods as hot, as where the sun doth rise,
We have no golden mines to lead you to,
But hearts of proof, and what we speak, we'll do.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: We thank you uncle and now must chide you;
If we be welcome to your country,
Why is the ancient league now broke betwixt us?
Why have your heralds in the French King's cause.
Breathed defiance 'gainst our dignity,
When face to face, we met at Landersey ?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My heralds to desire your majesty?
Your grace mistakes, we sent ambassadors
To treat a peace between the French and you,
not to defy you as an enemy.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Yet uncle in King Henry's name he came,
And boldly to our face did give the same.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Hell stop that fatal boding emperor's throat ▪
That sings against us this dismal raven's note.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Mother of God, if this be true, we see,
There are more Kings in England now then we:
Where's Cardinal Woolsey?
Herded you this news in France?

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: I did my liege, and by my means 'twas done,
I'll not deny it; I had commission
To join a league between the French and him ▪
Which he withstanding as an enemy.
I did defy him from your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Dared thou presume so, base-born Cardinal,
Without our knowledge to abuse our name;
Presumptuous traitor, under what pretence
Didst thou attempt to brave the emperor?
Belike thou meantst to level at a crown ▪
But thy ambitious crown shall hurl thee down.

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: With reverence to your majesty, I did no more
Than I can answer to the holy sea.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Villain, thou canst not answer it to me,
Nor shadow thy insulting treachery:
How durst ye sirrah, in your ambassage,
Unknown to us stamp in our royal coin
The base impression of your Cardinal hat.
As if you were copartner in the crown?
Ego et rexme●s: you and your King must be
In equal state, and pomp, and majesty:
Out of my presence hateful impudency.

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: Remember my liege, that I am Cardinal
And deputy unto his holiness.

You that are cat●●●as, or great Cardinal,

There keep you till you hear further from us:

sp.speaker: Wool:
sp.l: Yet will I proudly pass as Cardinal,
Although this day define my heavy fall.

sp.l: I fear King Henry, and my royal uncle,

sp.l: In yonder tower ▪ there's a flower, that hath my heart.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Enough good William, you're too hard for all:
My lord the emperor, we delay too long,
Your promised welcome to the English court,
The honourable order of the garter,
Your majesty shall take immediately,
And sit installed therewith in Windsor castle,
I tell ye there are lads girt with that order,
That will ungirt 〈◊〉 proudest champion:
Set forwards there regard the emperor's state,
First in our court we'll banquet merrily,
Then mount on steeds, and girt in complete steel,
We'll tug at barriers, tilt and tournament:
Then shall ye see the yeomen of my guard
Wrestle, shoot, throw the sledge, or pitch the bar,
Or any other active exercise:
Those triumphs past, we'll forthwith haste to Windsor,
S. George's knight shall be the Christian emperor

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
